All Reviews

  1. I am SOOOO glad that I decided to go out on a limb and buy this! This stuff is seriously incredible! I have always had large pores, excessively oily skin and acne. I'm in my 30's and still battling skin issues. I bought some ACV to go with this product and have used it 2-3 times a week. I mix it in a little sandwich baggy which is less messy, I apply a relatively thick layer to my face and neck and leave it on for at least an hour (usually about an hour and a half) to make sure it's completely dry. You can feel the &#34;pulsating&#34; feeling as it dries and it does make your skin feel very restricted and tight while it's drying. Warm water and gently rubbing, sometimes with a washcloth, takes the mask off relatively easy (I haven't had any issues washing the clay off). My skin wasn't red afterward (some other users reported this) but my skin is SO SOFT!! I was blown away at how soft my skin was. Not to mention - this stuff really makes a difference! My makeup went on so much more smoothly the following morning and I definitely noticed a SIGNIFICANT difference in how oily my face was throughout the day. I am so excited about this stuff, it is a MUST buy for anyone who has oily skin or large pores!!
  2. this stuff is pretty crazy. it gets REALLY tight, almost to the point of uncomfortable on your skin! the first couple times I used it I think it did make my skin break out more, but I think it was just the &#34;purging&#34; because now my skin is the best it's ever been! I have cystic acne and I get blackheads on my jawline and I use this mask once a week and my skin is practically clear! it's really good for spot treatment too - when I feel one of the painful bumps coming up I just put a mask on for about half and hour and it literally deflates it within a day!<br /><br />I would recommend using ACV to mix instead of water - it mixes MUCH better and ACV also has acne fighting properties.<br /><br />it's a little freaky how red your face will be for about 30 minutes after but I've read that that is just because it's bringing all the blood to the surface/increasing circulation. apparently that's what makes this mask so powerful. I would definitely recommend it to anyone with acne or even just stubborn black heads...this mask is very cleansing!
  3. I tried this product the same night that it arrived and I was very pleased. I read the description and the container says that a single pound of this can make up to 10-15 facial masks. This is assuming that you're using it on your whole face. However, if you only want to use it on a certain portion of your face and you use it sparingly, you could easily double this usage. I took one of those very little plastic dishes that you would use for salad dressing, added the clay and water, and mixed it up. I didn't even need to use the whole little dish, so I popped the lid on and it sealed the moisture very well for the next use! I'll be buying this again when I run out.
  4. Pretty good at absorbing my super oily skin. Pulls dirt and oil out of skin. You will want to use a moisturizer afterwards to prevent over drying that can cause your skin to over produce oil. Mask tightens and cleans face. I haven't had any irritation, but noticed some reviewers saying that it caused irritation, so it may cause irritation for people with very sensitive skin.
  5. Irritated my skin a little bit but overall it's an awesome product!
  6. All I can say is WOW!!! I have extremely oily, acne prone skin. My pores are also very deep and always clogged no matter what I use. After using this mask ONE TIME my skin was practically flawless! Not only did it unclog my pores it also dried up my zits and then I even had to use moisturizer because it dried my skin slightly. But I am definitely not complaining about the drying of my skin - it needed that. I just eyeballed about 3 Tbs of dirt, added water slowly, mixing with a butter knife until it made a paste. I applied it as directed, all over (watch your eyes!) and about a 1/4 inch thick. I left it on for 10 minutes. One warning however, it does tingle, pull, and then got pretty itchy. I was so scared I was having an allergic reaction but then the itchiness went away after just a couple minutes. This is all normal. I then wet several soft paper towels with warm water and wiped it off slowly, throwing all of the chunks into the trash. DO NOT let the clay go down your drain as that can cause buildup. A little bit got into my drain but there was no problem with that. Then I grabbed my super soft microfiber towel and wet that with warm water to wipe off the remnants. My skin has never felt so soft! I am so excited to see how this would work on my back since I suffer from back acne, deep, nasty clogged pores, and very oily skin. I am one happy customer!!!!!!!!!!
  7. Exactly what the other reviews said! You'll feel this clay mask work. Your face will start pulsating and if there's nasty stuff under your skin, you'll break out a little at first, but for me, it was only like that the first two times. I try using this once a week, but it is kind of annoying to clean up because I don't let it go down the drain for clogging purposes...
  8. The sticker covered the instructions!! super annoying. Also, I accidentally used metal the first time... woops.

It's waaaay too harsh to use more than once a week. This and a bottle of apple cider vinegar are more than enough to last for a few months.
  10. I just used this for the first time today and my skin feels tighter and my pesky blackheads are gone! We all know how hard blackheads are to get rid of. It feels great on my face as well with the tightening sensation. This is the most amazing face mask I've ever used!

  13. THIS STUFF IS AMAZING!
  14. I have good skin that occasionally gets congested and a bit bumpy, but isn't overly sensitive or acne prone. I swear by this stuff when used with vinegar and I have been using it for years. I apply it fairly thick and wait for it to dry, which can take quite a while. It dries to hard and tight that it sort of feels like it's sucking your face off, but it gets everything - and I mean EVERYTHING - out of your skin that you want gone. The acid in the vinegar acts like a mini peel and will leave your face pink for about an hour after use, so I wouldn't use it just before going out.<br /><br />Use this once a week and follow with a good, non-chemical moisturizer and your skin will feel like a baby's.

  36. The first thing that surprised me was when it said there was no chemicals. I have combination/oily AND delicate skin, and I always use so many products that have chemicals and harm my skin; and many of those chemical products made my skin dry which caused my skin to be MORE oily. This product does tighten your skin and not every skin can tolerate something like this. My skin is delicate but there can be more delicate skin types. I always recommend to do a skin allergy or regular skin test to see if the skin can tolerate the product. I put a small amount on my wrist and a small amount on the area below the earlobe (I had three pimples there, so I luckily tested it out on how it worked on pimples as well). 13 minutes have passed and there was no irritation or allergic reaction and it left my skin super soft. (And on the next day, the pimples got smaller.)<br /><br />[You don't need that much for your face- 1 Tablespoon of each is really good for applying it to your face. You don't need more than 2 Tablespoons for the whole face.]<br /><br />It is always important to follow the instructions. If it says use raw apple cider vinegar and/or water, then get RAW acv and/or water. Don't put any oils or extra stuff that people say it's good when it's not. I did research on this product and they say to use raw acv and non-metallic utensils since metal with the ingredient with the clay won't cause a complete mixture and adding oils can ruin the PH levels that are for the treatment of your skin.<br /><br />I put the mask once with my fingers, and I had some areas that hurt more than others, almost causing a skin irritation in small areas. I highly recommend people with delicate skin to put on the mask evenly when applying it to your whole face. Use a foundation brush to apply, and it will give you an even coating. When you're done with the mask, dab your face with warm water before removing it from your skin (this will make it easier for you to take it off).<br /><br />When you're done- you will probably see your skin turn red but that is said in the instructions that it's a normal result. Wait for the red to disappear for a moment, and apply a moisturizer. You will feel it a little heavy, but it will go away. This is only an option that I put because some people need moisturizer for controlling the oils and some people don't. Exfoliate once a week for delicate skin. This is important because exfoliation can irritate the skin when doing it more than once. (Optional) use a steamer to help open the pores and make your skin soft.<br /><br />The results of having clear skin will take a while. The mask takes of all of the dead skins and helps fix the damaged ones. People have experienced to have more pimples for a couple of weeks until their skin got used to it. Remember, not every skin is the same but this is something that I can relate to people the most. There are so many products that don't help for people with combination skin and it does stink. But this mask can really help and I'm so glad it makes my skin feel baby soft and has caused many pimples to disappear after the first application.<br /><br />Good luck to all the boys and girls that have read this! I have faith that you will achieve your goal of having clear and soft skin. :)e done- you will probably see your skin turn red but that is said in the instructions that it's a normal result. I tried to get most of the dried on mask in the trash so it wouldn't clog my drain (as other reviewers said it would.) In order to do this, I peeled and scraped a lot of the mask off.<br /><br />In the process of peeling it off, I realized this stuff really does get into the pores. How? Well, if you have ever used the &#34;Biore&#34; Pore Strips or something like that... the best part, ripping the strip off to see the forest of pore clogging stuff stuck to it. Well, that is exactly what I saw when I was able to get a good piece of the mask off and held it to eye level. I saw that there were some blackheads and tons of other pore clogging debris on the surface. When seeing that, I thought this really does grab all of the junk that my cleanser and makeup remover towel leaves behind on a daily basis.<br /><br />After washing the rest of the mask off, my face was really red. I put my usual moisturizer on and within 15 minutes, it was back to normal but super soft and REALLY clean.<br /><br />Few things:<br />-The pulsating/tightening is really noticeable the longer the mask is on and starts to dry up. I made the mistake of walking really fast and the cold air really enhanced the tightening/drying of the mask almost the point of a little pain, but maybe it was the pain of ripping out all of the pore clogging junk?<br />-I mixed 6 tablespoons of clay with equal parts of raw apple cider vinegar, it made too much! I think 3 tablespoons of each would be sufficient for a face mask about a 1/4 thick.<br />-The smell is really not that bad. Don't let the recommended apple cider vinegar turn you away.

  57. This natural calcium bentonite clay is especially great for oily skin. It has been used in India for thousands of years and I have been using it for 30 years, it's really no secret that it helps cleanse the pores and tighten the skin. It used to come in little pieces in plastic bags when I was growing up but now it's ground and sold in a jar by Aztec Secret. USA is one of the biggest producers of this clay but it is also mined in several countries around the world.<br /><br />It's a natural cleanser, and is also used to clean marble of all impurities as marble is a porous stone. The Taj Mahal in India is being restored slowly to its former glory to take away the grime built up with the ages by applying this clay to it and scrubbing away.<br /><br />When I was a teenager with oily skin I would mix this earth with a little cucumber juice (grate a cucumber and squeeze through a cheesecloth) and a few drops of honey and apply it as a mask. It took care of any acne and left my skin glowing. Nothing worked better for my skin, really!<br /><br />It works best with oily or combination skin. For dry skin it's best to mix it with a little moisturizing agent like milk cream and honey (and a little water) to apply so it does not dry your skin out. It really cools the skin and according to age old wisdom and is best applied in summer months as it can be too drying for winter. There are some active compounds in it and it can be strong so don't apply it to very delicate or sensitive skin before testing.<br /><br />It does tend to get everywhere so tie your hair back but remember it washes off and does not typically leave any stains. In fact, in India some even use it for shampooing the hair, so it's definitely not bad for hair.<br /><br />Go ahead, use this ancient beauty secret and enjoy your glowing skin!

I mixed the water and acv in the bag and then poured little bits of the clay into the bag, I locked the zip bag and gave it shakes until I got the consistency I was looking for, adding more clay as needed. I used a makeup brush to apply it evenly. After I applied it, I sat back and read some of the reviews and I felt exactly what was posted; the tingling, the pulling, the pulsations, etc. Once my 20min were up, I went to my bathroom, grabbed a few sensative babywipes and turned on the hot water and gently cleansed off the clay. I let the hot water run in my sink to make sure my sink doesn't clog. So far so goog. Quick, easy, and no mess.   111. I tried this for the past three months and I will never be without it. I have mostly oily skin, especially around my nose and I break out almos all the time on my chin, a history of cystic acne on either side of my mouth since age 19. I am now 34 and after years of different systems I found this clay to be the most effective part of my routine. I use it every other day. I mix 1 tbs of clay and one tbs of organic apple cider vinegar (essential) and let it fiz while I mix it. I apply it and let it sit on my face until it's almost completely dry. I use a warm wet washcloth to wash it off. I then apply my zit cream. Followed by lotion. I can say that while it may be weird and uncomfortable, the results are worth every second. It has even gotten rid of old acne scars. Pores are pretty much gone. My boyfriend is a diesel mechanic and this is sometimes the best thing to clean his oil and brake dust encrusted nose pores. This is an amazing product.

  113. I am an esthetician and here is my review based on actually using the mask...<br />First, if you have oily skin and aren't very sensitive, use the apple cider vinegar for mixing; if you are sensitive use distilled water. Second, DO NOT USE ON YOUR ENTIRE FACE more than once a week. This mask is powerful and literally pulls EVERYTHING (water, dirt, oil, etc) out. If you use it on your entire face too often, it will cause your skin to over compensate for the loss of healthy moisture and oil, which will bring more unwanted oil production and breakout. My advice is to spot treat acne and to leave it on those spots overnight (do NOT leave on your entire face overnight). By morning you should see a noticeable difference. Also, while this clay is awesome, you still need to figure out the root cause of your acne and get on a healthy skin care and diet routine to really combat any skin issues.

I've found a microfiber cloth takes it off much easier than a washcloth.<br /><br />My skin feels cleaner afterwards, more plump (probably from the pulsing), and most of my sebaceous filaments are gone (until the next morning). THEN scrub/wipe it off.<br /><br />I only do this once a week because my skin is pretty normal and do not want to dry it out. So far the best benefit this clay has given is it's blackhead loosening.   145. I have always used face masks since my teenage years, mostly to combat acne as it occasionally flared. I am now 29 and for some reason my skin is out of control. I used my usual mint julep but the pimples just smiled and kept swelling. I saw this on amazon whole browsing and had to try it.<br /><br />it goes on easy and dries like a .....desert. It pulls and tugs your skin in different directions to the point you can feel a pulsing feeling. It dragged my face and I kind of looked like a gangster Robert Deniro I try to leave it on as long as possible, but often take it off before it is completely dry. My face will be temporarily red for about 30 minutes which is something I have never seen with other face masks. The skin feels tight and very smooth after removing the product. Getting the mask off can be a little challenge, even if you use copious amounts of warm water. The nice thing is that the gritty texture acts as a exfoliating scrub as you are removing it. The pimples look way better after the mask treatment. Not \\"dried out\\" exactly, although they are dryer than before the mask. Pimples are less inflamed, less red, and it even seems that it helps with post blemish hyperpigmentation (those lovely spots that linger after a pimple- varying shades of brown, red, purple etc..)<br /><br />tips-<br />--I used a food processor to mix mine. I first mixed by hand and it turned out clumpy. I dumped equal parts into the little chopper/mixer and it made a nice smooth cream that was easy to change in thickness by adding fluid.<br />--Use the raw apple cider vinegar, just order them together and don't waste your time without it. Not only does it mix better than water, its a natural antiseptic, analgesic, and reduces inflammation. It can be used as a toner once it is watered down. One bottle lasts a long time, its very potent.<br />--Make a bunch at once and put the remainder in a small Tupperware. The only thing I miss about mint julep is the easy to dispense squeeze bottle. No one wants to have to break out the powder, vinegar, bowl, spatula and spend time mixing every time you want a mask! If you make a decent quantity, its easier.<br />--Read the directions and follow the directions on usage. It recommends applying 1/4to 1/2 inch on the face. Do you know how thick it is?. THICK! If you apply generously as recommended, you get the full benefit. It also seems to tighten the skin more, the more you put on. Go for it! It will take more than 10-15 minutes to dry, but whatever.<br /><br />Overall I think this is the best mud mask out there. I know its dirt, or whatever, and I know some people question what the reAl ingredients and authenticity of those ... It works, who cares!<br /><br />I work for a plastic surgeon, and this mask is better than most things we sell as far as a safe, all around facial treatment that has no downtime and can be used by any skin type, while allowing the ability to customize the intensity and effects by adding a diluted apple vinegar solution vs water, or lighter vs heavier layers.<br /><br />I've been using it every other night for the past week, and it has accelerated my non-healing pimples into smaller, manageable, HEALING PIMPLES. My skin isn't really dry, but I can feel it starting to become dryer than normal, but, I've been hitting this mask hard so I expected that.<br /><br />its worth a try, its affordable and bullet proof. Plus, if you like to FEEL something to know its working, you will love this mask.<br /><br />good luckut the powder, vinegar, bowl, spatula and spend time mixing every time you want a mask! If you make a decent quantity, its easier. --Read the directions and follow the directions on usage. It recommends applying 1/4to 1/2 inch on the face. Do you know how thick it is?. THICK! If you apply generously as recommended, you get the full benefit. It also seems to tighten the skin more, the more you put on. Go for it! It will take more than 10-15 minutes to dry, but whatever. Overall I think this is the best mud mask out there. I know its dirt, or whatever, and I know some people question what the reAl ingredients and authenticity of those ... It works, who cares! I work for a plastic surgeon, and this mask is better than most things we sell as far as a safe, all around facial treatment that has no downtime and can be used by any skin type, while allowing the ability to customize the intensity and effects by adding a diluted apple vinegar solution vs water, or lighter vs heavier layers.   149. This is exactly what's written on the bottle. I use it once a week, and I have to say, I'm in love with it. It's nice rubbing your face with dirt. c:<br /><br />That being said: DO NOT MIX WITH WATER<br />DO NOT MIX WITH WATER<br />DO. NOT. MIX. WITH. WATER.<br /><br />You will end up with a clumpy, gross, nasty mess that will not be pleasant and leave you cursing the name of clay. Instead, mix with apple cider vinegar. Go ahead and buy a small bottle. I know, it sounds odd to have to rub that onto your face, but trust me, your skin will love you for it. The pH balance of the apple cider vinegar will not make you break out into terrible, horrible rashes.<br /><br />When you want to make a good clay mask, get about 1/16th of a cup (and I recommend a glass mixing bowl) and then get your apple cider vinegar. You won't need a whole lot - and always err on the side of less. Less is more. 1/8th of a cup makes enough for me to cover the faces of me and my mom. . . with two coats.<br /><br />Anyway, dribble just a little in. Make a little wet spot. It will crackle and fizz - congrats, the magic is working. Mix with a wooden spoon, and immediately, you'll see the magic working. It'll be smooth, clump-free, and although it smells faintly of apple cider, it'll feel amazing. With the spoon, your fingers, or a brush (recommend the brush) apply it on your face.<br /><br />Leave one for 30 minutes - or until it's dry - and wash off.<br /><br />Some faint redness is expected and normal, so don't worry. I recommend a small dose of moisturize of your choice - my skin always felt a little dry after I took off the clay mask. If you have skin prone to breakouts, this is a great product to use. However, expect a minor flare up - clay tightens your pores and sucks out the oil that way, so it draws impurities to the surface.<br /><br />And don't use this product more than once a week. Over exfoliating is bad for your skin!

I leave it on for about an hour (until it's totally dry) it hasn't dried out my skin but must have pulled out the fungus that causes Psoriasis. To use this product it comes dry in powder form, you add some to a bowl with water but the product is smoother if it has a day to sit mixed with the water. If you make too much it will mildew so to prevent this put it in a bowl with a lid and store any unused wet product in your freezer.

I've never had a problem with it being lumpy. You can literally feel it drawing the &#34;gunk&#34; out of your skin as it dries! I'm left with incredibly smooth and soft skin and my pores are considerably less noticeable. I could not be happier with this purchase. After using it for only a week, I'm already singing its praises to any friend or family member that will listen. Another friend that has been using a bentonite clay for years told me there are many other uses, so I plan to be experimenting soon. For now, just using it as a mask is giving me more than my money's worth back in results.<br /><br />It can take you a bit to figure out how much powder and liquid to mix. If you end up with too much, you can store it in a ziploc baggie or a glass jar and use the rest later. This way there is no waste.<br /><br />Because it works so incredibly well, you may want to use a good moisturizer afterward. When I'm using it for acne or enlarged pores, I follow up with a dab of good quality coconut oil and a drop of tea tree essential oil.   205. I typically have clear skin. My skin gets shiny by the end of the day, but it normally stays pretty clear. My big skin problem, however, is blackheads. I have them all over my nose, my chin, even sometimes on my cheeks and forehead! I've tried scrubs, strips, masks, lotions, and they've usually only helped minimally. Next, after patting my face dry, I mix the clay with the apple cider and spread it on my face. I leave it on for 15-20 minutes, as advertised, After I wash it off, I follow with Bior&eacute; anti-blackhead strips, and voil&agrave;!   217. This mask is amazing. I have sensitive, acne-prone skin that is just starting to age, and is dry almost all the time. I have tried so many different skin care products, and I have found very few that make a huge difference on my skin, and this is one of them.<br /><br />The directions on the back state that you can mix this with equal parts of apple cider vinegar or water. I chose to use the apple cider vinegar because so many people stated that when they mixed it with water, it clumped up and wouldn't mix well. The apple cider vinegar that I used worked really well and made it easy to mix. You really need very little to make a thick mask that covers your entire face. I made a mask for my husband and I, and I still made too much (I used a quarter cup of the clay and a quarter cup of apple cider vinegar). I think two tablespoons of clay and two tablespoons of apple cider vinegar would be plenty for one person.<br /><br />I used organic apple cider vinegar, and I'm not sure how much of a difference that makes, but I wanted to use pure ingredients. When I initially mixed the mask up, it puffed up some of the dry clay into the air and started fizzing, which kind of scared me actually, because I hadn't read anything that said that it would react like that. I had flashbacks of my chemistry teacher saying don't mix bleach and ammonia if you don't want to die, so I set the bowl down and moved away until it stopped fizzing. It actually mixed very nicely into a creamy texture, and felt pleasant when I put it on my skin. I soon felt like the mask was tightening and it felt a little tingly, but really nice. I didn't notice a burning sensation at all, which I was worried about since I have such sensitive skin. I left it on for 10 minutes (it says 5-10 minutes for sensitive skin and 15-20 for non-sensitive skin), and noticed it was really hard to wash off with just my hands and warm water. I used a wet paper towel because I didn't want to ruin my washcloths. It falls off in clumps, so I'd recommend washing your face over your kitchen sink if possible so you don't clog up your bathroom sink or shower. It took about 3-5 minutes of light scrubbing to get the mask off, and my face was red, red, red. The directions say redness is normal and should last about 30 minutes. I would say it lasted about 2-3 hours, honestly. I may have left it on too long, so next time I will try for 5-7 minutes instead of the full ten minutes. While I didn't feel it burn while I had it on my face, I did notice my face felt like I had a mild sunburn once I washed it off. I used REN Hydra-Calm Global Protection Day Cream, which usually calms my skin right away, and it kind of felt like when you put aloe on a burn, so it felt better immediately. You could probably use pure aloe (it's pretty cheap at Trader Joe's or use a plant if you have one) and it would make your skin feel better too.<br /><br />The next day my skin felt really clean and my pores looked clean. My skin looked healthier overall and my pores were smaller. I had less dryness around my nose area, which was great because usually clay masks dry my face out so bad my face will itch for days after using one. This clay is great if you need a deep cleansing mask that you only need to use once or twice a month. I really think if your skin is sensitive like mine you probably wouldn't be able to handle it more than once or twice a month because it is irritating. You get a lot for a good price, so I think this will probably last me 6 months to a full year. This will probably be hit or miss with a lot of people just because it can be super irritating to your skin, but for under $10, I don't think it would break the bank for most people.ls off in clumps, so I'd recommend washing your face over your kitchen sink if possible so you don't clog up your bathroom sink or shower. It took about 3-5 minutes of light scrubbing to get the mask off, and my face was red, red, red. The directions say redness is normal and should last about 30 minutes. I would say it lasted about 2-3 hours, honestly. I may have left it on too long, so next time I will try for 5-7 minutes instead of the full ten minutes. While I didn't feel it burn while I had it on my face, I did notice my face felt like I had a mild sunburn once I washed it off. I used REN Hydra-Calm Global Protection Day Cream, which usually calms my skin right away, and it kind of felt like when you put aloe on a burn, so it felt better immediately. You could probably use pure aloe (it's pretty cheap at Trader Joe's or use a plant if you have one) and it would make your skin feel better too.<br /><br />The next day my skin felt really clean and my pores looked clean. My skin looked healthier overall and my pores were smaller. I had less dryness around my nose area, which was great because usually clay masks dry my face out so bad my face will itch for days after using one. This clay is great if you need a deep cleansing mask that you only need to use once or twice a month. I really think if your skin is sensitive like mine you probably wouldn't be able to handle it more than once or twice a month because it is irritating. You get a lot for a good price, so I think this will probably last me 6 months to a full year. This will probably be hit or miss with a lot of people just because it can be super irritating to your skin, but for under $10, I don't think it would break the bank for most people.

  224. I just HAD to write a review. I got this in the mail at noon today and all day I couldn't wait to use it as a facial mask (apparently it has other uses too like for your feet and body wraps!).<br />I just got done using it and I am absolutely shocked by the results; I wish I had a before and after to post! What I did is I steamed my face for 15 minutes, extracted as many blackheads as possible with a comedone extractor tool (but my blackheads have always been really stubborn- like permanent scars, so I only got to remove about like 10), then I put the clay on my face using apple cider vinegar (make sure it's organic) and a brush. I left it on for 20 minutes and removed it. ALL OF MY BLACKHEADS ARE GONE! I am so shocked!!! My T-zone is completely covered in blackheads... Basically every pore. I've had them for about 4 years with no luck of removal and now they're finally gone! I am so happy! I am definitely sticking to this product. Hopefully it will do wonders to my acne. I will definitely buy more in the future when I run out.<br />Pros- removes blackheads, leaves skin feeling baby-soft and fresh, makes skin feel super clean and fresh<br />Cons- Kind of made my face itch in some places, super, super messy during removal<br />Make sure you either rinse your face outside or cover your drain with a towel or washcloth... The clay WILL clog your drains if you don't. Also, do not use any metal spoons or bowls when you mix the clay (says so on the package). I washed my face with face wash afterwards too and applied a little bit of moisturizer. I hope you have as great results as I did!<br /><br />PS- I will make an update to this if it seems to clear up my acne in a few months.

I recommend making 1 tsp of clay/apple cider vinegar for oily skin, 1 TBSP lasted me a week of use and I still have extra in the container, if anything if its too little you can always mix up more.<br />- I tried the bowl of water to trap the clay mask, and I tried the plastic bag storage/applicator, neither one rocked my world. Don't dump the clay down your sinks though, many reviewers have mentioned it causes issues and the headache isn't worth the 5 extra seconds it takes to fill a bowl to dump outside later.<br />- I apply with my fingers, pull out a makeup remover and get the excess product off, one day when I make the time I'll get a brush for application. Wait the 15 minutes until dry, mist my forehead liberally with water and then wipe off the product, then misting/wiping my nose and so on.<br />- I use this in my regular beauty routine. I wash my face, apply the mask and wait til its all dry (normally around 15 minutes) remove the mask, then I use the Simple Micellar cleansing water (or a toner if you want), serum, moisturizer with SPF and voila! Nothing on earth works that quickly, I don't care where this clay came from. If you want to sit two inches in front of the mirror and analyze every pore for a couple of hours then yes you will see a difference in your skin.<br /><br />In honesty, the notice in change came the morning after for me. I noticed that my skin looked more even, clear and healthy. My face looks refreshed and clean. After about two weeks, using it once per week, I did notice that my blemishes were starting to subside. But it took a little bit of time. 2 weeks to see a noticable difference in blemishes and pore size. Yes everyones skin is different, but skin is also like the rest of our body. It takes some time for solutions or treatments to work. Whether you have troubled skin or not, I would recommend this clay. But I would never lead someone to beleive that this will cure all ailments over night; and certainly not in twenty minutes.<br /><br />I will continue to buy this clay.   273. I'm a bit confused by the extreme reviews for this product. It is a simple raw powdered bentonite clay which is readily available all over the world and used in many many cosmetics that you probably have in your bathroom right now. The marketing on this product is hyped, of course it is, almost all cosmetic products are touting unrealistic benefits these days. Bentonite clay is not a miracle, but it does have beneficial, productive uses both internally and externally. Sadly, it will not heal your acne or make you beautiful overnight, it may take TIME to get the results you want, and your expectations have to be REALISTIC. Educate yourself about this product (or rather bentonite clay, you can get it much cheaper than this) and then decide if it's right for you and your situation.<br /><br />Good things about Bentonite Clay:<br /><br />-Contains over 70 trace minerals.<br />-Absorbs Toxins, Impurities, Metals, & Other Contaminants from the Body (used both internally & externally for these purposes)<br />-Can sooth muscle damage, bruises, cuts & wounds.<br />-Astringent & Antibacterial Properties<br />-Filled with Negative Ions (which bind to bad positive ions like certain bacterias and cancel them out)

  287. This is the first skin care product I've EVER used that has actually substantially helped the appearance and quality of my skin. And I've tried more products than I could ever count. I have extremely oily, acne-prone skin; I even sometimes get awful cystic acne, it's so bad. This product has helped immensely.<br /><br />Firstly, you definitely never want to mix with water--you'll just end up wasting clay because water makes the mask very clumpy. I always make my facial mask with organic raw apple cider vinegar with 'mother'; it mixes beautifully and results in a nice, smooth application. Not only that, but this specific unfiltered type of vinegar is shown to help regulate sebum (skin oil) production in the pores. Do some reading on the skin care benefits.<br /><br />I usually leave the mask on for 30-45 minutes, which is a bit longer than what the packaging recommends, but my skin is, like I said, extremely oily, way more oily than most people who complain of oily skin, so my circumstances call for 'stronger' skin care measures, if you will. Anyway, once the time is up, and the mask is basically half-completely dry, I gently wash off with warm water. I always do it at night because it leaves your skin very red. However, in the morning... HELLO! *angels sing*<br /><br />In the morning after a previous night's application, my skin is always, without fail, smoother, clearer, and most importantly: hardly oily at all! And the effect lasts for pretty much the entire day, maybe even partially into the day after that. My skin just feels healthier overall after I use it.<br /><br />If you're the 'average' oily-skinned person, then I'd recommend starting using it once a week, evaluate, then go from there. Everyone's skin is different and so different treatments will affect everyone differently. You might need to use it more or less often. Use it the night before a date, or a party, or some other social event, etc, once you've figured out how it works for you.<br /><br />So if you struggle with acne-prone or oily skin, I highly, HIGHLY recommend this product! Really, I am SO pleased. Even if you're on a tight budget and you think that 10-ish dollars is a bit pricey for 1 pound, it lasts a really long time.   311. Okay, let's get down to it: There are hundreds of rave reviews on this product, and like many other people reading through these, I thought it was too good to be true.<br />But hey, it's cheap, and it's natural--where can you go wrong?<br />I figured worst case scenario, I'd end up tossing it. Less than ten dollars, not that bad, right?<br /><br />Here's the rundown: My skin is difficult. It's sensitive to certain products and is somehow simultaneously really oily in the T-zone and really dry along my cheeks and chin. I've got blackheads all over my nose and three or four sizeable whiteheads on my face at any given time. I've also had dozens of very small bumps on my forehead for years. When I saw the reviewers of this product claiming that it made the pimples pop out of your face, I got a bit excited.<br /><br />Here's what really happened to me:<br />I started using the mask every other day, moisturizing well with Clinique's dramatically different moisturizing gel after every use. I found that while pimples weren't exactly popping out of my face, the mask did do a very good job of purifying my skin OVER TIME.<br /><br />What do I mean by that? The big pimples that I had got a bit bigger, and were gone within a few days. More importantly, the small bumps I've had on my forehead that I've never been able to get rid of? Within two uses (three days) they'd developed into full-fledged whiteheads. Then, a few days after that, they were GONE. And I mean, 100% gone, no sign they were ever there in the first place, and I've had those for YEARS. This clay doesn't kill the bacteria in your acne so much as it brings it to the surface--a process that is actually a lot better for your skin than killing the pimples with salicylic acid and benzoyl peroxide. It will make you break out because it is in fact purging your skin of all those nasty toxins. Once the pimples have developed fully, I would recommend using a comedone extractor (can also be found on amazon--I got mine for $0.79 and free shipping) to extract them, and then swiping over with a toner of your choice (that's when you use salicylic acid or BP--in the toner.) Your pimple should be gone within a day or so.<br /><br />I've found that using this clay every other day to start with is very good, if a bit hard on the skin. Just remember to moisturize well after each application. After the initial purge is over, maybe switch to using it once or twice a week, just to maintain. It's a good preventative treatment in the long term, because it doesn't let the toxins in your skin develop long enough to turn into full-fledged pimples. If there's bacteria, it's coming out. After the initial purge I stopped breaking out altogether, and I know it was mostly thanks to this mask because I stopped using it for a month or so and my acne came back full-force.<br /><br />I mix it one part clay powder to one part Bragg's organic ACV with \\"the mother.\\" I use two teaspoons of each clay powder and ACV, because I've found that the mask DOES work better if you put it on very thickly. I spread it on my face with my fingers and then use an old paddle foundation brush to smooth it out and attempt to even out the coverage. I then leave it on for half an hour.<br /><br />BEFORE PUTTING IT ON: make sure to thoroughly cleanse your face. DO NOT moisturize or tone--NOTHING. I've found that it works a lot better if you run a washcloth under hot water, wring it out, and press it to your face to open your pores. Leaves your face slightly damp and your pores open as an excellent prep for the mask. Set the wet washcloth aside in order to take off the mask.<br /><br />TO TAKE IT OFF: I read in the reviews here that a lot of people had trouble taking the mask off. In the beginning, I tried wetting my hands and slowly peeling off the chunks. Not only was it nearly impossible, but it hurt too. I've found that if you take the same washcloth you used to prep your face before the mask and run it under warm water, then press it into your face to loosen the mask, it comes off easily! Just wet the mask and when it's loose rub in circular motions with the washcloth and it comes RIGHT OFF. If it's not coming off, that just means you need more water!<br /><br />In conclusion: this mask is fantastic. It's not a miracle, but it works VERY well, especially for the price. Make sure you know how to use it and be smart about your expectations. You shouldn't be disappointed. Good luck!t into your face to loosen the mask, it comes off easily! Just wet the mask and when it's loose rub in circular motions with the washcloth and it comes RIGHT OFF. If it's not coming off, that just means you need more water!<br /><br />In conclusion: this mask is fantastic. It's not a miracle, but it works VERY well, especially for the price. Make sure you know how to use it and be smart about your expectations. You shouldn't be disappointed. Good luck!

I mixed with the spoon until all the little clumps were gone and then I applied it with a foundation brush. I mixed it kinda of thin because I was afraid of the clogging of my sink after I read the reviews.

Just a warning though, it can be like concrete when it dries, so don't just try to rub it off unless you want your entire dermis to go with it, I would suggest taking a wet towelette and holding it on your face for a while to soften the clay first before wetting the cloth again and using it to gently rub it off. I must say that I like the feeling when the mask dries up & I have not experienced any side effects or discomfort. This is no miracle mask but it does its job. Oh boy, let me tell you.<br /><br />It's kinda gross looking, and mixed with apple cider vinegar it won't smell nice. Putting it on your face, you won't look like a young starlet. I've been putting this on twice a day, morning and before bed (maybe excessive, but I've only seen positive changes, one must experiment) for about two weeks, always followed by a good moisturizer. I had just suffered a mammoth breakout, worse than I've had in months. This mask stopped the progression of more acne, took the damage that was already done, and slowly but surely subdued it. It's like a ninja. A slow but effective ninja. It will take time...weeks, probably months. Yes, it's a bit of a stretch if you're a long time acne sufferer to assume this mask will magically heal you in a few days' time. But give it a chance to work over the course of a few weeks, and you won't be disappointed. My red spots are fading, everyday I see a difference. The skin in-between blemishes is much cleaner and healthy looking. And whenever a zit rears its bastard face, this mask is like &#34;NAH, not on my watch&#34;.<br /><br />You're still here? Expensive stuff, advertised by so called &#34;dermatologists&#34; and scientists. Forget all that. Buy this. Make the commitment to use it as much as you need. Mix a bunch, put it in some airtight tupperware. Put this crap on once a day, couple times a week, whatever you can do. With discipline, your fight against acne will be reinforced by this vigorous cavalry. And for me personally, I finally feel that the war is turning in my favor. DO IT.for themselves.   365. This is seriously an awesome product, but should only be part of your bags of tricks for overall skincare. If you already aren't using a cleanser, a toner, and a moisturizer with sun protection everyday then this will not be the magic end-all be-all of products.<br /><br />A bit of background on my skin type; it is generally considered combination and is breakout prone, however I sway to only slightly oily and slightly dry. I have large pores and often treat them with a BHA liquid.<br /><br />The reason I got the Clay is because of all the minerals it can deposit into your skin and to help tighten pores, which this does very well. However, the biggest suggestion I can make is do not...I repeat DO NOT use this with Apple Cider Vinegar! I have seen success stories on other posts, and for those people that's fantastic. However, ACV is not a proven ingredient in topical skin care! When ingested, it has great benefits for skin, but doesn't do anything for the surface of the skin but smell funky and do a little bit more exfoliating. If you are somebody who is applying this clay purely for the removal of dead skin, then be my guest and mix ACV with it. I mean, if ACV is as great for skin as many people claim, why hasn't there been more companies to include it in their formulas? For me, it just doesn't make sense. Plus, there are several people who are severely allergic to it, causing nasty bumps on the skin.<br /><br />How I personally get the most out of my clay treatment is directly after cleansing, I mix this 1:1 with distilled water and add a teaspoon of my favorite toner. The toner that I find most beneficial for my skin type is the Paula's Choice Purely Natural Gentle Toner. I find that this toner has a lot of really great antioxidants and some really great ingredients that feel great on the skin. I also like to add a few drops of Melaleuca AKA Tea Tree Oil to help with my acne-prone skin. However, if you use a Benzoyl Peroxide already I do not suggest this addition. Just make sure that your toner does not contain any sort of Alcohol or other potentially irritating ingredients; remember, it's staying on your face for at least 15 minutes!<br /><br />This mask is supposed to stay on your face for a long time, why not get the most out of the best ingredients?<br /><br />To take the mask off, let your face soak in water to soften the clay. Don't try to scrub it off, just wash it off nice and easy. Follow up with your regular routine, and you are good to go! Do this once or twice a week, spot treat with it when you need it, or use as tolerated. The results from the mask may be temporary, but if you have damaged skin like I did this can be a crucial part in helping you heal faster.Just make sure that your toner does not contain any sort of Alcohol or other potentially irritating ingredients; remember, it's staying on your face for at least 15 minutes!<br /><br />This mask is supposed to stay on your face for a long time, why not get the most out of the best ingredients?<br /><br />To take the mask off, let your face soak in water to soften the clay. Don't try to scrub it off, just wash it off nice and easy. Follow up with your regular routine, and you are good to go! Do this once or twice a week, spot treat with it when you need it, or use as tolerated. The results from the mask may be temporary, but if you have damaged skin like I did this can be a crucial part in helping you heal faster.

  397. First off, you WILL need vinegar to get this clay dissolved. Water alone did not work for me, but you can combine a little water and apple cider vinegar and the clay will dissolve properly. Otherwise, it's impossible to get it into a smooth consistency.<br /><br />Secondly, you do not need a half inch thickness for your face, or whatever thickness the package recommends. A thin layer works just fine. I think I use about a teaspoon or less and an equal portion water/vinegar mixture.<br /><br />Thirdly, the clay will get very hard, but once you wash it off, it does leave your face really smooth. It also works well for drying out acne if used in certain spots.<br /><br />Overall, I'm happy with this product and can tell it will last me a long, long time. Good buy for the price.

  402. Let me first start off by telling you my skin type. I have very oily skin, which means that I am also acne prone. Next was the preparation, I have read plenty of reviews and many people said that it was time consuming. I guess that is understandable if you used water. It won't mix properly. While using the apple cider vinegar it was very easy to mix. I did a ratio of 1:1. 1 tablespoon of the clay and 1 table spoon of the vinegar and it mixed beautifully and was just the right amount for the face. The application was simple and the smell of it really didn't bother me, I actually didn't really smell the vinegar at all. It began to dry very quickly, and was completely dry in 25 minutes. I began to feel my face pulsate, and at the thirty minute mark I washed it off. I saw many people say that it clogged their drains, and I found a way to get the mask off of your face easily while not clogging your drains or making a mess! Take a bowl and fill it with warm water. Make sure the bowl is big enough to fit your whole face in and submerge with water. After it is completely dry and it's time to take it off, just dunk your face in the water for a few seconds (5-10) and begin using your hands to scrub it off. It comes off pretty easily and isn't messy, unless you make a wave pool with the water and the next thing you know its all over your counter and floor...Then once you are done pat your face dry with a towel and look at your face, woah it's red. Don't worry, it's normal and goes away! After using this...I can honestly say that I have never been more happy with a product. My pores are so much smaller, and my black heads are almost completely gone! My skin is baby soft! After using this on your skin and it is completely dry remember to go in with a moisturizer, because now any treatment you want to use with sink right in. I use the Garnier Moisture Rescue Refreshing Gel-Cream. The redness will go down with time. My skin looks awesome!   422. This stuff is great, but only if you mix with an acidic liquid, in order to balance the ph, since the clay itself is highly alkaline and will destroy the skin if you use with water alone. I tested the ph using strips and confirmed. So Apple cider vinegar or lemon juice is best , since both are equally acidic. However, if you use lemon juice, you need to stay away from the sun for several hours because citrus makes skin photosensitive. I think the instructions on the pack should not even recommend mixing with water. Also, it's important that you measure carefully and use equal parts of this clay and ACV. Wrong proportion will influence the ph of the final paste you end up with. A thin layer will do.

  428. I don't know why this clay does what it does, but it certainly made my hair react differently that it has to other hair products...and in a good way. I have natural kinky curly hair (3c/4a) and heard that this clay works wonders on our hair. So, I mixed up a half cup of the clay with equal parts aloe vera juice (for best PH level) little by little until it had a pudding-like consistency. Then I got in the shower, wet my hair and started squooshing it in, section by section, from root to tip, until my whole head was done. You MUST do this in the shower or the clay mixture will get all over everything in sight. Then I put a plastic cap on for about 20 minutes, THOROUGHLY rinsed it all out and then conditioned hair and scalp with TRESemme Naturals Nourishing Moisturizing Conditioner (my favorite). My hair was definitely clean and soft after, but the big surprise came later when it was dry. My curls had a lovely defined but looser pattern that I don't normally get. I almost felt that I could do a wash and go for the first time in my life! I braided it that night for stretch, and the next day my hair was just gorgeous. It wasn't frizzy, the shine was very nice and the curl definition was perfect. I must say, I didn't expect anything when I tried this clay, but I definitely saw a difference from what my hair normally does. Because it's a bit messy to use (like Henna without the color all over the place), I will only do this once a month, but will absolutely keep it in my regimen. I have also used this clay mixed with apple cider vinegar for spot acne treatments and it works very well for that too. All in all a great inexpensive product that does what it says it will do and then some.

  458. Background: Female, mid 20s. I’ve been breaking out since I was 8 years old. Went through 3 rounds of Accutane over the years (I hold the honors for being the youngest patient MY dermatologist ever prescribed it to, bow down). I bought this clay in May ’14 after reading the reviews. Then I got stage fright and never used it. “It won’t work for ME,” I thought, skimming the reviews. “This is the usual case. Everything works for other people who swear they didn’t think it would work for them but then it did. It won’t work for me because I have such awful skin. Woe is me.” I uncovered the jar 8 months later and was like “well, I bought it. Might as well try it.” I had no plans that night so I made trying this secret clay to be my big plan for the night.<br /><br />I realized I had no idea how much to mix and I didn’t feel like combing through the Amazon questions and reviews to see if anyone gave out measurements. I’m not really good at winging it with measurements. It’s not a strength of mine. Just tell me how much to use! I think I made it too liquid-y on the first go-round. Though it did harden. 10-15 minutes in, I started feeling panicky. This was my first try at a mask and I didn’t expect it to be so tight. Was I having an allergic reaction? Was I allergic to apple cider vinegar? (lol) I CAN’T TALK OMG SO TIGHT. I never really felt the pulsing? Just tightness. It’s intense for a first-timer! I went to take the mask off and realized “um wow okay this stuff is really, really, really hardened on there” and I had no idea whatsoever how to get it off. I used a pre-moistened face wipe but that didn’t really work. So I got a wash cloth with warm water. I have very fair, sensitive skin so when it did come off, my face was BRIGHT red. They warn you of this but I was still shocked at how red my whole face was. It was a jarring difference between the areas where I didn’t put the mask (like around my eyes) and the areas where I did. And of course then my friends asked me to go out. Not looking like this! Anyway. They say to expect 30 minutes of redness, but I had to wait a little over an hour before my skin returned to a normal, not so alarming, color. I moisturized after about 15 minutes. One review here said they use witch hazel, I might seek that out.<br /><br />The next day, my skin was SO soft. I couldn’t believe it. I was the weirdo in line at CVS stroking their own face. Haha.<br /><br />I used it again the next night because I was eager to try again and play around with it some more. This time, I made the mixture in a cheap bowl from the dollar store. For the people who are like me and need step-by-step, I used 1 tablespoon +1 teaspoon of apple cider vinegar and the clay. A few reviews mentioned using a make-up brush (makes sense but I immediately was like NO! I love my brushes too much) and the only brush I felt okay using this mixture with was some tiny cheap brush so that’s what I used to paint the mixture on more evenly.<br /><br />And! The most exciting part: the pulsing! I DEFINITELY felt it! So my second time around trying it I definitely improved: 1) I put it on more evenly (thanks to the brush) and I felt the pulsing, which to me, signified that it was working the way it was supposed to. The pulsing= weird feeling! Same really red face as the first time, and it took a little longer to “cool down”.<br /><br />The next day, my face was smoother, softer and generally looked better. I bet over time this will help with acne scars. I really can’t wait to see what using this stuff for 3 weeks will do!nd of course then my friends asked me to go out. Not looking like this! Anyway. They say to expect 30 minutes of redness, but I had to wait a little over an hour before my skin returned to a normal, not so alarming, color. I moisturized after about 15 minutes. One review here said they use witch hazel, I might seek that out.<br /><br />The next day, my skin was SO soft. I couldn’t believe it. I was the weirdo in line at CVS stroking their own face. Haha.<br /><br />I used it again the next night because I was eager to try again and play around with it some more. This time, I made the mixture in a cheap bowl from the dollar store. For the people who are like me and need step-by-step, I used 1 tablespoon +1 teaspoon of apple cider vinegar and the clay. A few reviews mentioned using a make-up brush (makes sense but I immediately was like NO! I love my brushes too much) and the only brush I felt okay using this mixture with was some tiny cheap brush so that’s what I used to paint the mixture on more evenly.<br /><br />And! The most exciting part: the pulsing! I DEFINITELY felt it! So my second time around trying it I definitely improved: 1) I put it on more evenly (thanks to the brush) and I felt the pulsing, which to me, signified that it was working the way it was supposed to. The pulsing= weird feeling! Same really red face as the first time, and it took a little longer to “cool down”.<br /><br />The next day, my face was smoother, softer and generally looked better. I bet over time this will help with acne scars. I really can’t wait to see what using this stuff for 3 weeks will do!

  466. Okay. It took me a minute to get the consistency I needed to make a clay mask...it reminds me of the Queen Helene Mint Julip Face Mask without the fragrance. It feels good to the face when it's starting to dry, and rinsing off was relatively easy...I just used a warm, wet washcloth for the removal. Clean up, afterwards, was easy, as well. I would recommend using it no more than twice per week, and only once per week if you have sensitive skin. If you have a bad problem with acne and oily skin use Apple Cider Vinegar to mix it rather than water. If you have dry skin and acne, use Sweet Almond Oil, or Avocado Oil, to mix it...and just leave it on for the 10 minutes, no longer. You really don't want clay to dry all the way on your face...as it gets harder to remove. Always follow up with a cleanser after taking it off, and be sure to use a mild astringent after that. I use Witch Hazel (organic, fragrance free) and there have been no skin reactions to so much being done at once. I really like this clay. I like that there is no fragrance, and that it is so simple and easy to use.

  483. This stuff is amazing! Although it is pretty messy. I mean, it's literally mud. The best (and cleanest) way I have discovered to do this is to make a bunch of mud and store it in a tupperware. Add some water and clay into the tupperware until you get the right mixture, then stir with a plastic spoon until all the lumps are gone. Then you can apply the mud to your face with the back of the spoon - this way your hands stay clean - and just rinse the spoon off when you're done! I keep the spoon in my makeup bag. A little strange, but it's convenient. The consistency of the mud gets a little weird just sitting there after a few days, but all you have to do is add a bit more water and stir and voila! more mud for your cleansing pleasure.

  499. At first, I thought this mask was too drying and too harsh and made me break out.I have used it for years -- on and off. My skin is usually sensitive, dehydrated (lacks water not oil) and acne prone. Hoorey for me.<br /><br />If I use this weekly, my skin stays clearer. Other factors affect my sensitive breakouts and this mask does not CURE anything.<br /><br />You can add:<br />Aloe juice<br />Home brewed teas<br />Oils (I used olive and had soft gorgeous skin afterward, but too much oil is no good for me.)<br />Use as shampoo for problem scalp -- see other good reviews on this!<br /><br />One thing worth noting: skin likes to stay more acidic (pH balance of 6-sish) and this clay is very alkaline. That's why it fizzes when you add vinegar. For breakouts, I prefer to balance this mask with an acid. I don't get the same results when I use water alone.

  512. I am very happy with this clay mask. I always mix it with apple cider vinegar to a clump free, whipped texture and leave it on until it is all the way dry. It is NOT a magical acne cure for me, however it definitely is helping that situation by cleaning out my pores. It is easy to make a big mess if you're not careful, and I caution against dry clay going down your sink drain- it could easily create a clog! I've been filling up my mixing bowl with water to dissolve it further and then flushing it. My only word of caution is to be GENTLE taking it off and make sure you use lots of water because it can easily pull of your top layer of skin and cause redness.

On day 2 after using the clay, my face started to peel and I wish that's a good sign.<br /><br />I don't feel really hateful towards the product because before my purchase, I read both positive and negative reviews on Amazon and reread them before finally deciding to try the mask. I used it at my own risk and so should you. Now, I got what I paid for and I am about to pay more since I'm meeting a skin specialist tomorrow. Hopefully my face recovers very soon.<br /><br />No complaints about the seller (Health and Beauty Pros) since I bought this with Amazon Prime. It arrived promptly.

  515. Let me begin by correcting all of those concerned about their drains. Bentonite Clay is perfectly safe for your drains, even if you have a septic system. Having been concerned when my product first came, I researched this. I live in the French Quarter(old pipes, old septic system, old everything!) and found that it is even safe for septic systems. It would take between 30 and 50 years to possibly even start to make a layer of clay that would potentially cause it to need to be pumped. There are people that have claimed they notice their drains stay more clear(probably partly due to the acidity of the vinegar.)<br /><br />As for the mask, I love it! It really sucks on my face and pulses. I follow the directions on the package and it only takes me a teaspoon of clay and vinegar. My face is very red afterwards, but I use Retin-A micro nightly also. I make sure to moisturize immediately after, then wait an hour to do my Retin-A.<br /><br />I use this for a clay detox bath a few nights a week...it is relaxing, and it helps with my aching joints and back. I am hoping within a few months of regular use to see many of my skin issue clear up. These include: KP, Acne, dry skin, uneven tone etc. I also hope the baths help alkalize and detox me enough, so I stop having some of my chronic health issues.<br /><br />Updates in the future!

The acid is what makes it pull tight, and the ACV I bought was only 5% acidity. I also put too much on (the directions say 1/4-1/2\\" thick but just layer it on a littler thicker than a normal mask, otherwise it won't dry fast enough.) After rinsing this off my face with warm water, I washed with my L'Oreal RevitaLift Radiant Smoothing cleanser and then applied my AcneFree 3-in-1 Night Repair Foam and my Neutrogena Firming Moisturizer.   530. I have extremely oiy skin with very large pores and being 42, I have tried everything to address these issues. Some items have helped temporarily or reduced their appearance under makeup, at least until everything is washed off. Nothing has ever given me any noticeable long term benefits. I realize the lumps don't interfere with the effectiveness, but they just irritated me (probably because I am a little OCD!) A few weeks ago I decided to try lemon juice and I hit the jackpot! I barely stirred the mixture before it became a fluffy, mousse like consistancy, completely free of lumps! I was able to apply it to my face with ease using a fan brush (of course you can use your fingers, but I am broke and trying to pretend I am at the spa, lol!). For the first time I was also able to apply a very thick layer as the lable suggests. I sat in front of a fan and watched tv. I kept it on for about an hour or so (as long as I could stand it) because it became so hard and tight! I literally stuck my face under the faucet with warm water and rinsed thoroughly with my hands for about 4 minutes until every bit was gone and finished with a cold water splash. I am extremely pale and my face was very pink for about 45 minutes afterwards. When my face had dried completely, I applied a few drops of Kiehls Midnight Recovery Concentrate and when I woke up the next day, my complexion was absolutely flawless and glowing! Of course my pores are still there but they are MUCH smaller. Since then I have repeated this procedure every 3 or 4 days and the results just keep getting better and better and my skin seems to be producing less oil. I also tried it without applying any serum or cream afterwards and the results were just as good. I am hooked for life and plan to stock up. I realize that if I quit using the mask my pores would probably return to their original size but at least I have found something that gives me noticable results that last for more than one day at a time. I can see a real difference without anything on my face :)producing less oil. I also tried it without applying any serum or cream afterwards and the results were just as good.   547. All you need is a sandwich bag.<br /><br />1. Tie and pin back any hair. This stuff gets everywhere.<br /><br />2. Put a scoop of clay into the sandwich bag. Add water or vinegar. Seal out all the air inside the bag and knead it into a smooth paste. Adjust with more clay or water as needed until you get your desired consistency.<br /><br />3. Partially flip the sandwich bag inside out on your hand, like a glove. Apply the clay to your face with your bag-glove. Your hands don't get dirty and you won't need any additional utensils.<br /><br />3. Let dry 10-15 min and remove with facial wipes (the pre-moistened kind). Alternatively, you can rinse it out into a basin or bowl, but don't do it into the sink or shower because it'll eventually clog your drains. It's mud.<br /><br />4. Moisturize. The good thing about this sandwich bag method is that if you have any extra (and I always make too much), you can just keep it in the bag for the next use. You literally bought a jar of dirt off Amazon; don't waste it. Seal out all the air to keep it from drying.<br /><br />[Protip #1: If you don't wash your hair every day, apply this stuff before you shower on a non-wash day. When you finish, just rinse it off. Time saver!]<br />[Protip #2: Dried, this stuff looks like boogers. So clean it out extra carefully around your nose to avoid awkward public situations.]<br /><br />HOORAH. It's clean, it's cheap, and it's easy. And you won't have to throw out a single bit.<br /><br />As for the review of the product itself, I can't attest to that as well as the other reviewers. I'm several years past my teenage bad-skin era. I use this mask to deep clean my pores around once a week, which it definitely does. This is in additional to cleanser/moisturizer 2x daily + exfoliating every few days so I have consistently good skin. However, the other reviews of this product's effectiveness are stellar, and that's what convinced me to buy. :)

  580. I was a little skeptical when I got this product, but within not even a week my pores shrunk just a tad bit. It's very messy when making the mixture because you have to mix powder with liquid and it's hard to blend to a good result. After applying the first time my skin felt really smooth. The product basically tightens up your skin so your pores are going to shrink. After applying it for a few more days after my skin would get a little red in areas that are kind of sensitive but it really did disappear even though I thought it wouldn't. It's easy to apply though after you mix it all together. I will update if my blackheads all disappear within a month or a couple months<br /><br />UPDATE!!!<br /><br />So I have been using this product for a couple months now- not religiously though. When I first started using it after a while my face started to react. Started getting red sort of so I stopped using it everyday sometimes 2 or 3 days a week sometimes not even a week or whatnot. Anyways, I've probably used it 50 times since I got it a long time ago. Every time I stop using it my pores get bigger and when I use it they shrink, but seriously THIS PRODUCT IS AMAZING. Honestly, it is messy. But what I did is I made it into a cream, which saves you more clay powder and makes the product last REALLY long. Just take a jar or a cup make sure it's one that you never really want to use again but that it's clean, and add the powder in and some water. Depends on you how much but too much clay makes it too hard and too much water makes it too watery. Think of it like making brownie or cake mix. Let it sit for a day or two and the clay will turn into mush, like mud. If you're going to not use the clay for a couple days then just put a fair amount of water so it doesn't dry up due to evaporation.<br /><br />All in all, this product is amazing. I can feel my face itch and it's as if it's squeezing my face and letting all my dirt and oils and icky stuff into the clay so it can harden and I can wash it or peel it off. This takes a lot of time though, and after your face stops itching or you can't feel it anymore that means it's done!<br /><br />But seriously, very significant changes to my face after using it, if I would of used it more often I know my pores would be gone because they shrunk from a size 10 to a size 2.ff. This takes a lot of time though, and after your face stops itching or you can't feel it anymore that means it's done! But seriously, very significant changes to my face after using it, if I would of used it more often I know my pores would be gone because they shrunk from a size 10 to a size 2.

  596. I've always suffered from Acne and understand it takes more than once or twice to use a product to know if it will work. Most people freak when they break out worse when using a new product. It's perfectly normal as the bacteria is flushing from your skin. Skin has several layers, the epidermis is basically 25-30 layers of dry dead skin, so you can imagine how long it takes for new skin to turn over.<br /><br />I've been able to control my acne with a good basic cleanser (no harsh stuff) and a mild face scrub 3 times a week (skinceticals has a good one but its pricey) . I'm trying to save money and go more organic or &#34;from the earth&#34; based products. I switched to coconut oil for eye make up removal, diluted apple cider vinegar wash and needed a mask/scrub so I'm trying this.<br /><br />With that said, I've only used the product once so far (just got it tonight) I tried the baggie method someone else mentioned (thank you!) and it worked well with mixing and applying. I mixed with organic apple vinegar cider (with the mother in it) and it did fizz a bit. I applied it really thick as instructed. I left it on for 12 minutes. NO one has mentioned the smell that I've read so far. Apple Cider Vinegar STINKS! But it is very good for your skin, so I breathed through my mouth the whole time. I wasn't sure how to remove it without getting in in the drain so I figured it would be a trial and error process. I got a rag I didn't care about throwing away and a bowl. I used super hot water on the rag and wrung it out and laid it on my face to soften the mask (like they do at the spa), then rubbed the mask off keeping the chunks inside the rag and using the bowl to dump the clumps into. That worked well and I didn't have to re- rinse the rag during the process. I noticed the areas where I applied thinner mask, were the most red. Where the mask was thicker, were barely pink right after removal. I wonder if there something to the thickness level that is causing bright redness for some people? I rinsed in the sink once everything was off to make sure no residue was left (another step people miss, causing breakouts). I used the rag to remove the chunks from the bowl and tossed the rag and washed the bowl. I need to find a better way as throwing away rags is not resourceful at all and I don't buy paper towels. I'll look through more posts and see what others are doing. I really don't want to clog my drains or my washer.<br /><br />My skin feels super soft and the pores appear tight. I put on a good moisturizer (another key component) and will report further findings in about 6 weeks of use. Which should be the minimum time given for any product to really do their job as it takes a long time for skin cell turnover.ess for some people? I figured, for less than $10, why not? I had no idea of how much to mix up, I mixed half a cup. Don't do that, unless you just want to have a very large quantity of mud to keep in a sealed container for the next few months. Try a tablespoon at a time, until you know how much you require. Just saying.<br /><br />I was amazed at the results. My acne wasn't horrible; it's all but nonexistent now. She used to get huge zits all over her forehead, so we are extremely happy with this product, just on that count. My 9 year old only uses it on her chin, where she is prone to blackheads.   641. This is one product that I keep in my medicine cabinet ALWAYS! I mainly use it to fight acne in 2 different ways.<br /><br />1. I create a face mask that I rinse off later on while bathing in the tub. I use a small ceramic bowl, add about a tablespoon of the powder and slowly add small amounts of water while stirring. This will prevent the clay from clunking up. I prefer a thicker mask so I add just enough water to create the mask. Then I place it all over my face and neck. If I have extra I place it on my upper chest. You will immediately begin to feel tingling. Your face will then begin to tighten as the clay mask begins to dry. You may even feel your face pulsating. I draw a bath in the meantime. Once I am done with my bath or when the tightness is too much for me, I remove the mask with a washcloth. Simply wet the washcloth with water and pat on the mask to moisten. Then go over again in circular motions until mask is removed. You will have to give your bath an extra rinse since the clay may stick to the tub.<br /><br />2. I also use the clay for problem areas. Since I too tend to have cystic acne, I immediately mix a small amount of the clay/water and place on the problem area. The clay will reduce the inflammation caused by acne. Sometimes I leave on overnight. I have seen other people suggest mixing the clay with apple cider vinegar so as to prevent harming the skin. So far I have not had any problems. Will try the ACV.<br /><br />This product is affordable and less expensive than all the other acne treatment products I've purchased in the past.
  642. I don't use it too often, just when I have break outs or need to clarify my hair. It is pretty awesome. I am going to start using it to prevent breakouts. I have been sleeping in my makeup lately (bad I know). So I will get breakouts from time to time. My pores have also become more noticeable. I put this mask on let it sit for a while. I feel the pulsating and squeezing. It maybe mental, but it feels like it's working. After rinsing it off most of the products I apply kind of burn. I don't know if this is because I exfoliate prior to the mask, or I use Retin A. Maybe someone else has had a similar experience. It doesn't seem to be too serious though. I also notice my pores seem to get smaller and if I use it before an event, my makeup looks more natural( I also don't have to use much) I would have used it more often in the past if I didn't have to mix it.Yes I am that lazy. I bought two tubs last year they are still full. I might start experimenting with body mask and putting it on ingrown hairs just to use it up. I will definitely buy this in the future.

Unless you just want it for a sort of conditioning, cleaning. Then do your thing. But you do need to be careful with this stuff. It's strong. I'm a fair-skinned middle-aged woman and this can give me broken capillaries. I like to use it just for the blackheads on my nose because it's so strong that it really pulls everything out in one go. When I do do my whole face my skin is definitely tighter and the pores smaller. No question. The redness goes away soon enough. But broken capillaries? Not so much. Bottom line? You can use it various ways to solve various problems. Just read the label and then experiment. No one else has YOUR skin. For me it's the best blackhead remover for my nose that I've ever come across. Looking like Rudolph the red-nosed reindeer for a half hour afterwards is a small price to pay. :)

If you use the moisturizer right after you take off the mask it shouldn't dry out your face at all. It didn't for mine anyways. But if you use it more frequently like 2x a weeks you should use a moisturizing face mask as well. The clay mask does leave your face red afterwards but it only lasts for 30 minutes.
