  1365. REALLY LIKE THIS PRODUCT, IT TAKE A VERY LONG TIME TO DRY DEPENDING ON HOW THICK YOU MAKE IT. I USE ACV WITH IT AND LEMON JUICE AND IT NOTICE FADING OF MY DARK SPOTS. ITS VERY CLEANSING, IT DRAWS OUT A LOT OF IMPURITIES BUT NOT EVERYTHING. I USE IT ONE A WEEK. I MIX IT IN A PAPER CUP WITH A PLASTIC SPOON SO WHEN I'M DONE I JUST TRASH EVERYTHING ALL TOGETHER, CLEAN IS REALLY EASY. I WASH IT OFF IN THE SHOWER. HADN'T HAD ANY PROBLEM WITH DRAIN CLOGS SO FAR.
  1366. THIS IS GOING TO BE A VERY LONG REVIEW BUT PLEASE, PLEASE TAKE JUST 5 MINUTES OUT OF YOUR LIFE TO READ THIS IF YOU SUFFER FROM ACNE.<br /><br />Wow. Where do I begin. Really, where do I begin. First, let me just say I have dreamed and prayed, literally dreamed of the day I can write a success story of my own in regards to acne. Any acne sufferer has tried hundreds of different products, read thousands of Google searches/reviews/blogs, and experienced an endless amount of frustration, pain, and confusion. I don't use the word embarrassment or humiliation, because you shouldn't be embarrassed nor should you be humiliated if you have acne. I have read thousands of reviews with writers saying they don't want to walk out the door or that they're embarrassed to face the world. You are who you are. These things happen. Acne is normal, it's everywhere. That shouldn't affect who you are as a person. Yes, it can be difficult to face the world. I can relate. But frustration and confusion are the best terms. Frustration because we don't know how to cure it. After trying every given product or method, it just doesn't go away. And confusion because sometimes we have no clue what is going on that causes all that acne.<br /><br />Now, let me get some facts out of the way. I'm a 21 year old male, college student. I've been suffering from acne for well over 8 years now. About the time I reached 13, obviously because of puberty and the typical growing phases, I was one of the unlucky ones plagued with pretty bad acne. It didn't get worse till about high school, but again high school is a time when we all go through improvements so having acne is not as bad. People get braces and go through other various stages during this time so it's no biggie. But in college, you really expect by about the time you're 18, your acne should be dissipating. And for most it does. But let's face it there will be and always will be a select bunch that still walk around with red spots all over their faces. Don't let that put you down. There are people out there who don't have proper vision, hearing, or worse disabilities. Now, I don't want to go into a pep talk lecture here, so let me get right to it, but I just want you all to know that 1) don't let this acne put you down.. and 2) THIS product will change your life.<br /><br />Here's the thing, I always read those reviews that say \\"this product may not work for you as everyone is different\\". I hate those reviews. That's rubbish. It's crap. It's true but that's the reason I hate it, because it's true. Every product may not work for you. BUT.. THIS product in particular is for everyone and doesn't present different, adverse effects on different skin types. Why might you ask? Well, it's simple. It's 100% pure dirt. Good ol' natural dirt. Literally that's what it is. The reason those OTHER products react differently on different skin types is because those are all products that contain chemicals, and different ones at that. So you can imagine. Obviously everyone's skin will react differently to various chemicals. Some good, some bad. This, however, is pure clay/dirt that will literally dig into the pores and flush out whatever gunk you may have.<br /><br />Now, I view acne at 3 different levels. Minor, Moderate, Severe. But on each stage there are another 3 levels. In other words, you may have Minor acne but may be on level 1, 2, or 3. A Minor acne sufferer with a level 3 may have worse acne than a minor level 1 and 2, but not as bad as one who would be listed in the Moderate acne stage. Same goes for if you are for example a Moderate acne sufferer but a level 3, you may not be so bad to the point of being a Severe acne sufferer, but in the Moderate stage you are still worse than others. If this makes any sense, I put myself at Moderate acne Level 2 and 3. On rare occasions, I hit Severe level 1 with a deep cyst or two, but haven't experienced that recently. Right now, my face is continuously at a Moderate level 2. Severe acne sufferers are those whose faces are literally clustered with severe red acne on every area of the face. Moderate would be one or two major sections (my two cheeks). Minor acne would be a small area like chin or just nose, or no major breakouts but a few pimples here and there.<br /><br />So all my life, like every other acne sufferer I have tried any and every acne remedy known to man. I kid you not. In the beginning (in my early teens) stages I tried the basic Neutrogena, Clean&Clear, basic drugstore crap. No effect there. As high school came around, I tried Cetaphil which proved a bit of an improvement, but again no cigar. I tried St.Ives peach apricot scrub for a while and that did some good stuff, but again nothing that could really vastly make an improvement. I tried masks, lemons, honey, yogurt, I mean you name it I tried it all. Don't even mention Benzoyl Peroxide. I tried a 3 step system and it screwed up my face. Anyways as I got to college, I came to face with the fact that I'm just going to have to \\"let nature run its course'. But still, I couldn't just let my face sit there and use lame cleansers. I can't begin to tell you how many hours I've spent doing acne research.<br /><br />My freshman year in college, I gave a shot at the AcneFree system and used Benzoyl P. again which again burned my face so I realized I'm allergic to it. For some, it may be useful. Not for a soft sensitive skinned fellow like me. So then I realized I may need to spend some money on high end products. Keep in mind I'm a college guy... I started getting on Sephora and looking at the hundreds of different products they offer. Oh and let me just add that my acne in college was the worst it ever got unfortunately. It seemed like every year from the day I crossed paths with acne, it just got worse and worse. Ok, so back to sephora. Over the span of a year or 2, I spent hundreds of dollars on different products (and I tried each for a few months to give it a true trial)... some worked, some didn't. But I can never tell what products truly \\"work\\" because it seemed like every week I would get a few whiteheads and ugly red, swollen pimples. The worst issue about my acne is that I also have serious hyperpigmentation from all the years prior. So I tried things like Bio-oil, hydroquinone, etc.<br /><br />I tried even more extreme methods like chemical peels, and even spent $750 on a 6 week session of microdermabrasion. The microdermabrasion REALLY improved my right cheek and forehead, and today it's quite clear because of it. But for some reason I still would get major breakouts on my left cheek. After I stopped the microdermabrasion sessions, again my breakouts started coming back (even on the right side and forehead). I tried more stuff like Dennis Gross peel pads and Peter Thomas Roth pads. I can go on and on about the products I tried, but the point is.. none of them made the difference I wanted to see, or prevented breakouts. Best put, preventing breakouts is the ultimate goal. That wasn't happening.<br /><br />Now to this product. I decided to give this a shot about 3 weeks ago, just because once again desperation led me to another product. Because of the really high reviews and people writing success stories, I was filled with hope. I read one guy's review who mentioned that he's a college student male and puts it on his face every night and isn't even embarrassed because it prevents his acne. I am in the same boat as him. I put this on every night. Sometimes I skip a night, but regardless I get this stuff on my face 5 out of 7 days. Do it at night so that your sleep can recover the skin and in the morning you'll look like a million bucks.<br /><br />I never thought there would be a miracle product, because we've always been led to believe there really isn't a miracle product. But let me just tell you, THIS IS IT. I kid you not. Like I said, it's not a chemical. Of course no artificial/machine made product is a miracle product, but thisfine clay dirt that's been around for centuries is... Oh let me just add I came across a prescribed professional line called M.D. Forte. It's quite pricey. I started using the M.D. Forte III 30% Glycolic Cleanser last December, and it has done wonders for my skin. It's oil free, soap free, and very gentle. Now, every night I cleanse my face with the cleanser and use the mask (I leave it on for about 30 minutes). My skin after feels like a baby's butt. No kidding. Then after the mask, I cool my skin with 100% witch hazel (no alcohol). and moisturize. and Voila. That's it.<br /><br />Bottom line:<br />My acne is not 100% diminished, because like I said my skin has taken toll after years and years of acne. It will take time, but I KNOW I KNOW that this is the product that WILL and IS doing that. It is almost May. I will update this review in July and post some before/after pics. My before pics are ridiculous- it really shows how bad my acne has been. I can already tell this product is paving the way for success after 8 years, and hopefully with use of this I will be at ease. I will use this for the rest of my life. No joke. I'm going to really stock up on this stuff. I hope they never stop providing it for us. Right now, any pimple I get is completely halted after a night of this stuff.. even the deep cysts. Let me just warn you, the first week you will breakout. I broke out pretty badly (shows how all the other products never got the gunk out of my skin).. but I kept going because I read on it that it will happen and you should keep going. Week 2 came around and seriously my skin recovered and took the quickest 180 turn, even from how severe week 1 was. Now I'm in week 3, heading into week 4 and I don't get any major breakouts but any small (or large) pimple is completely healed by the next day. This literally flushes ALL of my pores.<br /><br />In the end, I'd just say use whatever cleanser (GENTLE cleanser) works for you. (oil free and soap free)<br />Make this mask (with Apple Cider Vinegar-- i forgot to mention.. very important. use apple cider vinegar)<br />Leave it on for 15-20 mins or 30.. depending on your skin.<br />Use witch hazel with cotton pads (trust me on this) gently wipe skin with it<br />Moisturize with whatever moisturizer works for you (oil-free)<br /><br />Try this regimen for a month and if you don't see major improvements, email me or contact me somehow and you can vent to me about your situation, but I promise this will work for ANY skin type because again it's completely natural there are no chemicals.. besides your cleanser and moisturizer, but that's why I advise using a quality, gentle cleanser. no drugstore brands please. they ruin your skin. go to Skinstore.com or dermstore.com and do some research on a gentle cleanser.<br /><br />On a final note, for some of you applying the mask every night may be too harsh. I'd say aim for 3 times every 7 days. I don't know how to end this.. I've been ranting for well over 10 minutes now, but clearly the reader can tell that I'm venting about this success story. I want to share it with the world. If you find this useful, please like the button that says you found it useful. Whether you have sever acne, moderate acne, or you're a well skinned jessica alba-type person, you can and will benefit from this. You are all beautiful .. EVERYONE is. but sometimes this crappy acne hides that true beauty. Again, don't be ashamed or embarrassed. It's something we can't control. Until now. With this mask, you can control it. PLEASE TRY THIS AND LET ME KNOW. I AM SO CURIOUS ABOUT OTHERS' success stories from this product! If you have any questions or comments just reply a comment to this review, I will check periodically.<br /><br />Like I said, my face is not clear JUST yet. My face still shows signs of moderate acne. That won't go in a few weeks. That's physically impossible. But I will keep you all posted and touch base in a few months! Good luck to you all and God bless! Try my regimen and see for yourself!<br /><br />Excuse me while I go out and enjoy this beautiful day and not let acne ruin my life :)<br /><br />****UPDATE May 29, 2014****<br /><br />Hello again peeps. I'm excited to say this is a GREAT positive update. I'll keep it short and sweet since my review itself is a novel...<br />I wrote the review a little over a month ago, and if you read my entire review and understood the whole acne minor/moderate/sever stage level thing, let me just proudly say that I am now a Moderate Level 1 and haven't had any severe or crazy breakouts at all! I used to be Moderate Level 3/Severe 1 as I mentioned. My forehead is completely spotless, my nose is spotless, my chin is spotless. The only two areas are my cheeks which as I mentioned were pretty bad from all the years of acne prior. I deal with hyperpigmentation (not scarring, but post red acne marks that linger for months), and this mask is seriously seriously even healing and brightening/lightening my hyperpigementation. All my red marks have reduced by shades of about 15 to 20% I'd say. This is such an exciting product. I also want to add that because I'm a DJ, I travel quite a bit and recently I was in New York for about a week and didn't get to use the mask at all. The entire week in new york I didn't use this mask and I didn't break out ONCE! This product clearly keeps acne/pimples at bay. I think by July as I mentioned, I should be significantly clearer.. which I cannot wait to see!   1391. A review for the \\"HEALING\\" part of the Indian healing clay. My husband had a sore on his knee that was infected, it was surrounded by very pink skin and it was hard underneath. The first night we put tea tree oil on it, that's usually my \\"go to\\" medicine for treating infections. By the next day there was no change, which alarmed me, then I remembered this clay. I made up a small amount (using water vs. ACV) that had the mud consistency and placed it on the sore and surrounding pink area of infection. We let it dry and then applied a large bandage to cover the whole area. He slept with it and kept it on the next day while he worked. When he got home and I checked it I couldn't believe the difference. All of the pink skin was now a normal color, it wasn't as sore to the touch and the hardness underneath was not as hard. It had drawn out the infection. So keep this in mind and use it for infections on yourself, your children, and even your pets.<br /><br />The first time I used this product as a facial, I mixed in apple cider vinegar. I definitely felt a tightening affect while it was on my face. When it came time to rinse off, I used a bowl because I did not want this going down my sink since it is mud. I poured it down the toilet. I'm glad I was not in a hurry to go anywhere because it took 30 to 40 mins. for my skin to return back to normal. My face was a bright pink after the facial and when I saw how pink it was I made a note of the time in order to see how long it would take to return to normal. After 30 mins. it wasn't as pink, after 40 mins. it was back to normal. So if you're going to use this as a facial leave yourself plenty of time. I gave myself a facial today and used water to mix instead of apple cider vinegar and the drawing and tightening effects were the same except that my face was not as pink as when I used the ACV. It took 5 to ten minutes for the pink areas to disappear from my skin.

  1403. A dear friend introduced me to the clay almost 2 years ago while I was recovering from Breast Cancer, and I've never stopped using it since. While in treatment, I was tired and looked run down. Enter the magic clay. I did a mask using raw organic apple cider vinegar and felt my face pulsing so much, I looked in the mirror to see if it was moving. It 'sucked' out so many toxins, I looked years younger. After completing radiation therapy and waiting 8 weeks for the full treatment to run its course, I made a giant tub of the clay using vinegar and water until it was smooth and runny, mixed it into a warm bath, grabbed a big bottle of water and rested for as long as I could take it. It was so intense, I did feel sick and had to lay down for the rest of the day. I'd read it could pull toxins out of your body and one shouldn't touch anything left behind in the tub after the water drains. I wiped it down with a paper towel and to my shock the residue was made up of black and metallic particles - it looked like glitter. I've done face and body masks with it regularly ever since. My skin looks beautiful. I rarely have a breakout. I feel energized. Most of all I'm happy with how I look and feel. One tub lasts about a year with weekly use. If using in a bath, mix 1 1/2 cups with enough water and vinegar to break it down to a liquid. Don't use with anything metal - I keep plastic forks handy to minimize lumps. Can't recommend more!

  1409. This is the best beauty product I have ever used. I always make it with boiling water. They suggest a consistency on the jar, but it's so hard to know what they're talking about. I came up with a formula and method I use myself, but I'm sure everyone does it differently.<br /><br />I boil water in a tea kettle, put it in a bowl, and slowly add clay (whisking constantly) until it is like butter-cream frosting. I do NOT suggest adding water to the clay, it absorbs really fast and you'll end up with clay balls, no matter how long you mix it. I don't worry too much about the amount, because I save extra in a food storage container. Next time, I put some in a pan on the stove and whisk until it's smooth and steaming, then whisk until it's cool enough to put on my face. Use it as hot as you can stand. Test!!!! Very easy to burn your face.

  1436. I have only used this a few times so it's difficult for me to say whether or not it's really helping with my acne. Purchased this based on the good reviews here about how it helps with acne.<br /><br />Just a tip: people talk about how difficult it is to wash this off since you don't want to wash it off and drain your clogs. I place gauze on my face and then apply this mask. If you wait until the mask is fully dry, the mask wil cleanly peel off with the gauze. There will still be a little powdery residue left, but you can actually just brush that off or rinse off. If you try to pull it off before the clay is dry, then only the gauze will pull off and the clay will remain on your face.<br /><br />I find this method to work the best. The gauze is porous enough that the clay rests on your face. And applying a thick layer means that when it dries, it will pull off in one piece. When I apply the clay straight to my face, it makes my face get red, especially as I wash it off.<br /><br />I also like to add some essential oils, such as niaouli, clary sage, and frankincense. Mix with clay and apple cider vinegar. Sometiems I also add a MSM capsule. I don't know that it makes my inflamed acne disappear overnight, but it definitely makes my skin feel really soft. Of course, that could be the apple cider vinegar.

  1451. Since there are so many reviews on the product itself, I thought I share one way to remove the mask.<br /><br />1) Rip a paper towel to a size that can cover your face.<br />2) Wet the paper towel and lay it on your face.<br />3) Gently press the wet paper towel against your face with your hands to allow water to seep into the mask.<br />4) Press it for 15 to 30 seconds or until you can feel the mud can move on your skin.<br />5) Slowly wipe your face with the paper towel. You can easily remove a good chunk.<br /><br />6) Turn on your faucet and let the water run very thin.<br />7) Close the stopper and try to open it very very very slightly so only water can escape.<br />8) Wash off the remaining mud that is left on your skin.<br />9) Turn off the faucet. Leave the sink the way it is.<br />***The water will be drained between the tiny gap while tiny mud pieces and particles will be plastered on the wall of the sink. *****<br />10) Just take a paper towel and give a sink a good wipe.<br /><br />I hope this may help a few people.

  1456. I read many reviews and bought this on the basis of skin clarifying, pore shrinkage, etc. I was absolutely astounded to see, after ONE use, its lifting effects. I looked 10 years younger! These were to be seen on my entire face, but the most powerful effects were on the areas above the eye, you know, those puffy places beneath the eyebrows that begin to droop over your eyelids as you get older. I mixed and applied this according to the directions on the jar, using [[ASIN:B001I7MVG0 Bragg Apple Cider Vinegar Organic Raw -- 32 fl oz]] (mixed up WAY too much, 1/2 cup of each, maybe even less, would have been MORE than sufficient). Anyway I applied it liberally in that area, and also in the eyelid crease and lightly on about the upper half of the eyelid itself. Absolutely unbelievable, puffiness and droop GONE.<br /><br />It lasted 2-3 days. I'll be curious to see if repeated use of the clay makes that effect more permanent. But even if not, who cares, this is the first product I've found that does that. Bear in mind that everyone's different, I tend to have crepey, loose skin (rather neglected, I'm afraid), so perhaps it won't have as pronounced an effect on those who've strengthened/treated their skin all along.<br /><br />Though I'm absolutely delighted with the lifting, energizing, and skin rejuvenating effects of the mask, I must say that I didn't see any sign of it dissolving or DRAWING gunk out of pores (let me hasten to add that all my pores are not full of gunk (!), I use one of those super-magnifying mirrors and I can see the few problematic pores here and there that do tend to accumulate it, I made a special point of looking at those). Years ago my grandmother had some special \\"drawing salve\\" that pulled out gunk, even dissolved blackheads, they don't seem to sell it anymore. The clay DID tighten and refine pores in general, however. Next time I think I'll steam my face and squeeze those problematic pores BEFORE applying the mask, to shrink them.<br /><br />One thing I would add is that I was really surprised at the POWERFUL tightening effects of the mask as it dried, so strong I couldn't even talk after it dried. I layered it on thickly (likely too thickly), then worried since it dried like veritable concrete that it might not come off, but it did, quite easily. I say all that because I used very warm water to ensure it would come off. Next time I plan to use cold water, because I'll bet the lifting effects will be even more pronounced, and may last longer that way. I've used other clay masks, NONE have evinced the effects this one did, FANTASTIC!br /><br />One thing I would add is that I was really surprised at the POWERFUL tightening effects of the mask as it dried, so strong I couldn't even talk after it dried. I did mix it with apple cider vinegar. I put this mask on 2x/week. At first, I ignored the new pimples because I believe it's the purging. However, after 2 months, my faith was crushed and I realized it was still getting worse (not even leveling). I couldn't handle the depression of looking at my pepperoni pizza face in the mirror anymore and stopped using this. Luckily after another 3 months, my face finally recovered. So! Lesson here is be careful if you want to use this to help with acne. Realize that there are different types of acne (blackhead/whitehead/papules/pustular/nodular/cystic), and maybe those with nodular and cystic type like me won't benefit from this clay :(

  1565. I'm sure my review will be buried under the masses of rave reviews, but I do have some helpful tips if any of you get a chance to see this!<br /><br />First, this stuff is pretty sweet. After quite a few trial and error, I've found a few things:<br /><br />1. BEST TIP - if you have any left over protein powder plastic scoops (c'mon I know you have a stash hidden somewhere that you swear you'll find a use for someday), you can just use one of those suckers to mix this mask in. Granted, you cant use a thimble sized scoop. Just use a regular one if you have it.<br /><br />2. Next, just take your scoop and gather a small amount from the clay jar. Then you can just pour in the Apple Cider vinegar in a 1:2 ratio (1 part ACV to 2 parts clay). It takes a while to find the right amt to get the desired consistency, but it's not too hard. NEXT just take a wooden chopstick and stir. Stir a lot . It's pretty neat cos once you pour in the ACV it all starts bubbling and snapping at you. When mixed thoroughly it has a kind of \\"whipped\\" consistency. Then you just smear all over your face/ back/ arms/whatever. Then you wait until it starts pulling and burning yo skin! This stuff burns my face as it tightens, then itches like crazy, then feels like someones throwing ice cold water at my face. I dont normally get a pulsing sensation, and maybe I'm doing it wrong, but I enjoy it so leave me alone!<br /><br />Anyhoo, I find the plastic scoop method works the best, and leaves minimal clean up, as opposed to using a kitchen bowl and spoon which tend to leave quite a bit more mess. Usually I can just get all the last bits of the mask out of the scoop with my finger, leaving the scoop almost totally clean, then just wipe the chopstick off on a body part to get all the excess off. Real classy like.<br /><br />I always see how long I can keep this stuff on; usually 20-40 min. It tightens your face to the point where you cant even open your mouth, so it's kind of a hassle if your significant other is home, and you can't do anything but whimper at them like you're a pre-oiled Tin Man. I highly recommend doing this when you are home alone.<br /><br />The clean up is the only crappy part of all this and I have yet to find a good (and easy) solution, save from hosing myself off in the back yard :/ I really hate the idea of using all the paper towels we own just to wipe it off, and I don't like the idea of using a bath towel (since that goes in the washing machine, and who knows how much that'll clog up the machine). As of today my solution to this issue is getting half off with paper towels then jumping into the shower and pretending like nothing will harm the plumbing. Sometimes I try to rinse off equal parts in all 4 of our sinks, just to distribute the mess evenly. Once again also pretending like that will not clog up our plumbing... I think the pretending is working!<br /><br />3. pro tip with the paper towel clean up - soak the towels in hot water, then lay it over your face for 10 seconds, then slowly drag the cloth down your face. If you just jump right in and smear the cloth over your face you're going to scream like Macaulay in Home Alone.<br /><br />4. When I first received this product, I used it 4 days in a row. Normally, using any kind of product that many days would wreak havoc on my skin, break me out, and dry the eff out of my face. Surprisingly enough, no damage has been reported. I have naturally dry skin that is insanely flaky, so after I clean the mask off I just apply a thick coat of Look, No X Ma! cream. I use that stuff religiously, and after the mask it works just fine.<br /><br />Results! I do see it working on my face. At least, I hope it's the mask. The right side of my face had a TERRIBLE disgusting break out for like, 3 months. I couldn't figure out what was causing it, and have tried everything natural to get rid of it... all the products only agitated it more, which was infuriating. After I used the mask 4 days ina row, I saw things clearing up a bit. Then I got lazy and quit, because the mess is just such a hassle, but now my acne's gotten a bit worse. Back to the mask!<br /><br />OH also, DO NOT LAUGH while this mask is drying. I made the mistake of watching SNL once to pass the mask drying time. once. Never again.<br /><br />Also, we now have a thin layer of grey, green clay coating over everything in the house (mainly the computer desk). But fear not, this stuff wipes right off anything. No biggie.<br /><br />Also, I saw people complaining that this clay is a greenish grey color, which they took to be \\"impure\\" because it wasn't white (racists!) WELL I read on a website from this super knowledgeable person that the white stuff is actually the over-refined/bad quality clay, so THERE. I mean, they seemed to really know their stuff, so I'll just choose to believe them over researching it more. It's the American way!<br /><br />Hoped any of this helped .. someone. Just one person, even. That would be worth it. ...a row, I saw things clearing up a bit. Then I got lazy and quit, because the mess is just such a hassle, but now my acne's gotten a bit worse. Back to the mask!<br /><br />OH also, DO NOT LAUGH while this mask is drying. I made the mistake of watching SNL once to pass the mask drying time. once. Never again.<br /><br />Also, we now have a thin layer of grey, green clay coating over everything in the house (mainly the computer desk). But fear not, this stuff wipes right off anything.   1592. Ok, so let me start out stating that this product works, it works ridiculously well. I'd recommend it to anyone to has acne problems, oily face, or even pop marks. I read over tons of reviews before purchasing the product and took all the advice I could to execute a proper use. I tried tons of different methods and this is the most efficient way I have personally found works. It's a bit of work, but it is worth it.<br />1) Get a bowl (I use a cereal bowl) and a whisk. Add the powder, then water (or apple cider vinegar, but I found it to be overkill with drying out my skin). Keep adding water/whisking until you get it to be a smooth paste. Heads up though, it will take a lot of elbow grease to get all the lumps out<br />2) Set it in the refrigerator and cover it. It will take FOREVER for the clay to dry itself out. I usually mix up a large amount. I found when you apply it on cold it will grip on your face and apply much more evenly. Avoid doing it warm, the results are far better when its chilled.<br />3) Get a bucket, and a old wash cloth. Fill the bucket up about a 1/3 of the way with water. You're going to want to avoid any of the clay going down your drain, it WILL clog it, and it is not fun trying to get solid clay out of your plumbing. So when you're ready to take the clay off, just keep wiping all of it off with the cloth and wring it out in the bucket. I do everything in my shower, and I have a mirror I can look at. This stuff can get everywhere so stay away from carpet, walls, furniture, etc. At the end, i'll just take the bucket and dump the clay water somewhere in my backyard.<br />4) Acquire a fan with a good amount of power. I use a 14\\" box fan. When you apply the mask, put the fan on full blast, and it will hasten the process so you can get on with your life<br />5) Everyone says to apply a thick amount. It really isn't necessary when it's cold. It will grip your face like an octopus, and the pulsating, tightening feeling is amplified in front of the fan. This clay can be applied anywhere on your body, and it's insanely cheap so don't be stingy. Your face will be red afterwards, it's normal, it's the blood being pulled to the surface of your skin.<br />6) If your skin is drying out too much from it, just moisturize right after, it'll leave your skin ridiculously soft. I find this product to be much more effective than any chemical face wash, such as Clearasil, pro-active, etc. And i've had less irritated skin when I stopped exfoliating it.an. This clay can be applied anywhere on your body, and it's insanely cheap so don't be stingy. Your face will be red afterwards, it's normal, it's the blood being pulled to the surface of your skin.<br />6) If your skin is drying out too much from it, just moisturize right after, it'll leave your skin ridiculously soft. I find this product to be much more effective than any chemical face wash, such as Clearasil, pro-active, etc. And i've had less irritated skin when I stopped exfoliating it.

  1626. I'm 36, with regular (but not cystic) acne, large, colors pores, oily skin within a few hours of washing, and a few scars. Simply put, I have bad skin. I have tried pretty much every thing else, from fruit extracts, to toners, creams, diet, etc. Still, the benzoil-peroxide routine not only works (if you stick to it) it works for most people according to doctors. And yet, with large pores and the occassional breakout (because I dont; stick to routine) I seek out products like these. Get sucked into the hoopla of fake reviews, that spawn real reviews from people moved by the power of suggestion, and the need to defend their purchase.And then there are the people that see and believe... but they don't understand.<br />When asked, my dermatologist specifically rejected the idea that clay would solve my problems. She said i can try, the the effects would be superficial. It would inflame and dry the skin, which immediately would shrink pores and reduce oil output. It would also close powers that need to breath, extract, are that size for a reason. It would be only a matter of time until the skin recovers and I would be back to normal. That would be within a few hours.<br />But look at all the reviews from people I don't know! It's curing people with skin like mine! Some people are curing joint pain! It works on poison ivy, and it can seal cracks in the basement wall! People even eat this stuff and it cleans their poop! It must be amazing! So i ordered 2 pounds of clay. A good time to mention, I have a degree in Environmental Science, studied clay and its formation, properties and uses.<br /><br />Excited to finally have a cheap product that will salve ALL my problems. I even bought into the &#34;Braggs Organic Apple Vinegar&#34; BS and mixed up a batch for my first go. I applied it. Waited. Waited... it's drying. it's shrinking. It's pulling my face with it! It pulsates and my body tries to flow blood into the area the clay is tearing apart. I'm gonna be cured!!!! I'm gonna be beautiful!!!<br /><br />This crap dries slow. Even in my low humidity apartment in the middle of winter with the heater making static electricity out of everything, the 20 minute dry time is more like 1 hour and 20 minutes. What an inconvenience. Then add in the torturous time i takes to peal and watch this crap off. Don't let chunks go down your drain or you will need to call in a pro to snake it out. It's messy and it'a annoying.<br /><br />So afterwards, there is my red, inflamed, pulsating face. I close look in my bathroom mirror and my pores are smaller! Yay! After one use, my pores are noticeably smaller and looks cleaner! A miracle! I look great! Of course bathroom mirrors and those frosted globe lights places just above them are designed to make people look great. The next day, as my face recovered (and broke out as usual) look at my skin under daylight, under fluorescent work lights, nothing has really changed. it's tighter and there's a layer of dry-dying skin that the clay decimated. But the pores are naturally the way my genes intended, my skin is still putting out the oil my genes tell it to, and i'm looking a bit more wrinkly because of that top layer of skin cells, now dying from getting the moisture sucked out of them.<br /><br />I tried again. Every night for 2 weeks. For sure it was just going to take a regimen to clean out those pores (yes clay does swell greatly in water, and when it dries, it can pull in moisture, oils, organics from its surroundings. But clay does not discriminate. It pull sin moisture from healthy cells. And it pulls in oils and organic chemicals natural to your skin. Simply put: any claims that this just pulls in toxins is scientifically false. It pulls in pretty much everything it can).<br /><br />The verdict: It does a great job of cleansing skin. Which is enough to show improvements in a lot of people that don't clean their skin properly, or just use a poor soap. It dries skin, which will temporarily reduce the size of pores and for some people reduce lines, for other people, create lines. It's a complete mess. It's a mess to make and apply, it's a mess to have on your face as it can take up to 2 hours to dry completely (the act of it drying is what cleans but also kills those top skins cells with dryness and makes people believe its actually shrinking pores). It cleans. It really does a great job of cleaning. It won't get deep into pores to clean out junk, but it does a much better job than most cleansers. TI does not do as good of a job as a cleanser with AHA (alpha-hydroxy acid), which can dissolve the gunk in your pores, and is usually prescribed/recommended by a doctor.<br /><br />So it does dry, tighten (and make it look like your pores are smaller until you shed that dry skin), and deep clean skin. For some people, the cleansing and drying is enough to battle acne. For others, this clay will cause acne through inflammation (probably for most people). But at what cost? Al that time to mix, apply... not touch anything, wait, wait, put your face on a space heater to speed it up. Then peel, wipe wash, clean, dry, moisturize, repeat? Just go see a dermatologist.ich is enough to show improvements in a lot of people that don't clean their skin properly, or just use a poor soap. It dries skin, which will temporarily reduce the size of pores and for some people reduce lines, for other people, create lines. It's a complete mess. It's a mess to make and apply, it's a mess to have on your face as it can take up to 2 hours to dry completely (the act of it drying is what cleans but also kills those top skins cells with dryness and makes people believe its actually shrinking pores). It cleans. It really does a great job of cleaning. It won't get deep into pores to clean out junk, but it does a much better job than most cleansers. TI does not do as good of a job as a cleanser with AHA (alpha-hydroxy acid), which can dissolve the gunk in your pores, and is usually prescribed/recommended by a doctor.<br /><br />So it does dry, tighten (and make it look like your pores are smaller until you shed that dry skin), and deep clean skin. For some people, the cleansing and drying is enough to battle acne. For others, this clay will cause acne through inflammation (probably for most people). But at what cost? Al that time to mix, apply... not touch anything, wait, wait, put your face on a space heater to speed it up. Then peel, wipe wash, clean, dry, moisturize, repeat? Just go see a dermatologist.

I didn't experience any clumps in the mixture as I've read some people who used water have. (Beware, though: the smell of the ACV is a bit gag-worthy, but a very small price to pay for the results.) I mixed them in a ceramic bowl with a plastic spoon because apparently you shouldn't use anything metal with this clay as it messes with the ions or something in the benzonite?<br /><br />I have very dry skin and I heard you shouldn't leave this on for too long or use it too often if you do. I leave it on for 8-10 minutes, and then hop in the shower to wash it off my face with water (no soap/cleanser necessary.) I've used it once a week since I got it and haven't experienced any dryness.<br /><br />I can't wait to see how much my skin improves with more uses!<br /><br />Highly recommend this product!!!

  1632. *~* So I absolutely love this stuff! I use it to make a mud wash/cleanse for my scalp (or shampoo, since that's what most people feel comfortable calling it). My hair & scalp absolutely love this clay. Whenever I have product buildup from hair products I simply mix this with apple cider vinegar, aloe vera juice (homemade: water & aloe vera blended or I leave the aloe vera soaking in the water overnight) coconut oil, and an essential oil into an applicator bottle and I have an AWESOME cleanser!<br /><br />*~* Now that I've explained how I use this clay, let me explain why I love it so much. The first 3 reasons are superficial, meaning they can be felt & seen by others than just myself:<br />1. When I apply this to my hair it becomes softer, after rinsing it out and the days after.<br />2. My hair looks extremely shiny, which is pretty amazing considering that I have pitch black natural hair (natural meaning textured & of African ancestry)<br />3. After use, my scalp is completely clear.<br /><br />*~* The 4th reason is pretty important to me & those who suffer from something similar or maybe worse. So even though this might seem a bit long it's worth reading still, for those who'd like to know.<br /> My Dad, as far as I can remember, always had a weird fungus on his scalp. It wasn't psoriasis, but it was pretty close. Thankfully I never inherited this from him, but, when I was about 9 or 10 he used one of my combs to pick out his hair without my knowledge. And yup, I ended up having that fungus on my head as well which made my mom furious with him. For the rest of that month my mom used a whole shampoo bottle of Nizoral on my scalp & effectively got rid of practically all the fungus except for two little parts on the nape of my scalp. Fast forward to 2013, I saw & read (through youtube & blogs) about some people doing a mud wash on their scalp to help them get rid of product buildup, dandruff, and psoriasis or to keep the psoriasis at bay for a while. So I figured, maybe it could help my nape area....Geez was I one happy camper after I used this for the first time! I've noticed that each time I use it there are less & less areas affected by the fungus I once had...AND THEY DON'T RETURN!!! I've only done this mud wash twice so far! I haven't tried it on my face as yet, but I will pretty soon since I've heard nothing but great things.<br /><br />*~* I hope this review helped someone or anyone dealing with a scalp fungus, psoriasis, or just plain old dandruff, & product buildup. Regardless, I think this is waaaay more effective than regular shampoo.   1633. I've struggled with milia for as long as I can remember. Milia are those hard, white bumps on your face that won't go away - they are not acne, they're clogged pores layers deep in your skin. I've been to the dermatologist, tried a prescription treatment, facials, you name it. I am reluctant to extract because they may scar. I finally found an expensive product that works (Elemis Cellular Recovery Skin Capsules.) At around $100 for a month supply, plus the slow-going of getting rid of these wretched things, thought I'd give this a try. It is working and I do see a difference. I still use the Elemis capsules, but no longer daily. I use this clay all over my face once per week, and do spot treatment once per week. Pores are noticeably improved. I have sensitive skin, but the clay didn't irritate. I did build up to the 20 minutes. Also, I originally used water as I didn't have organic apple cider. It's really hard to mix. I switched to the vinegar and for me, the difference was night and day. Easy to mix and it worked noticeably more (much more humming on the skin.) For the price, I absolutely recommend. I have one pesky milia spot that I can't get rid of. If this product does the trick, I'll update and say hands down, it works on this problem.

  1704. Bentonite clay is the same stuff companies use to manufacture kitty litter and more expensive prepared masks. You could hypothetically get kitty litter and crush it but this is a very finely ground powder. Any leftover will dry into flaky clumps. I tried to reused this, which albeit easier than kitty litter, and it is never quite the same as the original batch. Only make enough to use for one sitting. You can add things like apple cider vinegar, substituting for part of the water, and it will compliment the effects of the clay.

  1719. I was skeptical about this product. I read all the reviews on here about how it works so well, and I thought I might as well give it a try since I really have nothing to lose. My skin is oily, pimply, disgusting. I've had acne since puberty hit (which was a loooong time ago) and nothing has ever really worked. I've decided to switch my routine to all natural products and for the first time in YEARS my skin is clearing up. Before this I used the Queen Helene mint mask. It was all right, but after using it my skin was still clogged up. I was using apple cider vinegar as a toner already so I liked the idea that I could mix it with this mask. It's simple. I mixed my apple cider with this-- I have to say it's taken me a few uses to perfect the amount of vinegar to clay ratio, so you would have to try what's best for you. If you have sensitive skin, I would recommend you use water, because this will turn your face red. Bright cherry red. But it says that it will do so on the container, and it does go away after 30 minutes or so, but maybe if you use water it won't be so bad. I can feel the oil being sucked out, because as this clay dries it gets tight, if you leave it on too long it gets tight and itchy and really uncomfortable. This is not a mask you use to relax, this is the kind of mask that means business. I've used it for about a month now about 2-3 times a week, and the results are amazing. The first week I used this, my skin went through a purge. A lot of pimples and whiteheads that were underneath the surface started to come up, so I did panic a bit. But by the second week of using this, my face began to clear up. After a month I have a few pimples left over, but nothing to the extent of what it was when I started. Also to get this off, I have to use warm water and a wash cloth, and slightly soak the clay before it gets soft again. Because it doesn't want to come off. My skin is the best it's ever been and getting better. I think you should definitely try this out, and for the price, you really have nothing to lose., and for the price, you really have nothing to lose.

  1733. So, I bought this especially for my pre teen with blackheads that are multiplying by the day. She's been using proactive for about a year and they aren't getting worse, but aren't going away, either. The dermatologist scoffed when I told her what we're using, because she said that the ingredients in proactive aren't any different than what's in drugstores... people are just more vigilant about using it so it seems to work better...<br />but about the clay... I used it on myself to get an idea about what to expect. I a 42, with combo skin, large pores in the t-zone that are a struggle to keep clear. I mixed a tbsp of clay with 1 1/2 tbsp acv with \\"mother\\". I foamed and made a whipped, wet, frothy mixture. I put a THIN layer on my face and sat down to watch tv. The layer was thin, mainly because I mixed it thin...not the 1/2 in thick like the directions say... just couldn't bring myself to do it!<br />I waited for the tightening and tingling and forgot to watch the clock. The jar says about 10 minutes, but it took longer for it to dry and tighten/tingle, so it was closer to 15... and that was a thin layer! I can't imagine what a thick layer would need to dry. The tightening was similar to what I've experienced with masks. The tingling was expected, but still peculiar.<br />After 15 minutes, I rinsed gently with warm water... I didn't want to scrub. I followed with a cool rinse. My skin looked pink at first and got progressively redder... exactly in the borders of the mask. Thank goodness I didn't slosh some on my eye area! The pinkness turned progressively redder and took over an hour to disappear. Then I realized that the acv is an acid... I am remembering all my salad dressing making and how an acid is needed. Now I'm wondering if the clay is just used to hold the acid on the skin and if in fact, I just gave myself a acid peel! My skin looks the same as it did before. The pores look the same and all it does feel smooth... as if I just exfoliated.<br />I won't use it on my daughter... too harsh and I guess I was expecting miracles. Reading the 3, 2 and 1 star ratings was very illuminating and made me too nervous to use it on her, considering my redness. I'm not using it again... Just threw it away. Can't risk it. Too nervous about what the next few days will bring!<br />I'll update in a couple of days if I have any breakouts associated with this.   1783. This stuff is AMAZING. I've been using it for about a month now, and love it. I use it either every night, or every other night and my skin has not reacted like when I've used other masks in the past-which would be getting heavy breakouts due to \\"bringing up the bad stuff\\". Also, if used the way I've been using it (continue reading on tips for mixing) I expect this tub to last me at least a year.<br /><br />I have very oily skin and large pores that I absolutely hate...I read a lot of the reviews along with the description of the product and was specifically interested in what it could do about that. Well, it works. Maybe after some prolonged use, I'll see a long lasting effect on this front; but what it does do instantly is completely shrink your pores to the point of them being nearly non existent.<br /><br />As stated in other reviews, it is NOT necessary to use a super thick layer of the product. I've found that a nice, even layer enough to cover your skin is all that's needed. Your entire face dries within about 30 minutes and I keep it on as long as I can...However I can't help picking at it as I'm watching TV...Eventually a nice, cool wash cloth takes it off really well and your face is tight and feels super clean.<br /><br />When I first got it, I tried it out on my face, neck and chest. OUCH. My face was not bothered at all by the burning-which is a really itchy sensation but my neck and chest were. Apparently MY face can take the burn \\"pulsating\\" effect more than my body can, but that's just me. I don't have the issue of my skin getting really red after using the mask, but again-that's just me.<br /><br />Here's a few tips:<br /><br />**Mixing this super fine powder w/o getting clumps in a bowl is really hard, like-REALLY, REALLY HARD. I don't care how slowly you try to do it-clumps happen and are nearly impossible to get rid of. It's wasteful AND you have fat chunks on your face that don't dry.<br /><br />One of the other reviewers mentions putting it in a zip-lock type bag and THANKS to that awesome tip-it made the process much easier. Use a heavy-duty freezer bag, you don't want it to rupture when your squishing. Rub it between your hands and really squish the mixture so it's really smooth. It really is the best way to mix it...But I took it a step further. I decided to see what would happen if I mixed a lot of it and then refrigerated it so I wouldn't have to deal with the process each time. I'm glad I did! It works great, stays fresh and you have a supply ready to go whenever you like. Each time, you have to squish it up a bit in case some little clumps formed but it's very minimal.<br /><br />**If you're like me and have super large pores that would like them to disappear before you leave the house, but don't have the time for a full mask routine added to getting yourself ready for the world, then try this: Put a small amount where your pores are the problem, a thin layer is all you need, then use your hair dryer on cool until it dries, wait another 5 minutes then wash off. You get THE EXACT same results in the tightening of your pores as you would with the typical method of letting it sit until it's all cracked and ready to wash off.<br /><br />**Because the clay is very messy and has a drying effect, I would suggest using a glove to apply, it works best with a tight medical glove. No dealing with getting it out from under your nails or drying your cuticles. =)<br /><br />Enjoy your smoother, tighter, pore-less skin!a zip-lock type bag and THANKS to that awesome tip-it made the process much easier. Use a heavy-duty freezer bag, you don't want it to rupture when your squishing. Rub it between your hands and really squish the mixture so it's really smooth. It really is the best way to mix it...But I took it a step further. I decided to see what would happen if I mixed a lot of it and then refrigerated it so I wouldn't have to deal with the process each time. I'm glad I did! It works great, stays fresh and you have a supply ready to go whenever you like. Each time, you have to squish it up a bit in case some little clumps formed but it's very minimal.<br /><br />**If you're like me and have super large pores that would like them to disappear before you leave the house, but don't have the time for a full mask routine added to getting yourself ready for the world, then try this: Put a small amount where your pores are the problem, a thin layer is all you need, then use your hair dryer on cool until it dries, wait another 5 minutes then wash off. You get THE EXACT same results in the tightening of your pores as you would with the typical method of letting it sit until it's all cracked and ready to wash off.<br /><br />**Because the clay is very messy and has a drying effect, I would suggest using a glove to apply, it works best with a tight medical glove. No dealing with getting it out from under your nails or drying your cuticles. =)<br /><br />Enjoy your smoother, tighter, pore-less skin!
  1784. I like this stuff, but I don't think it's really that great. I have fairly mild acne. I get occasional little pimples and on rare occasions, I'll get a cystic pimple (I suppose this wouldn't do much to help with those kinds anyway) and I didn't really notice this help with my acne very much as I've seen other reviewers say. It's also kind of inconvenient to mix up every time. I guess if I liked the product enough, I would feel like this isn't too much of a chore, but since I just think it's okay, it feels like something I would rather not do. Consequently, much of this stuff is still lying around my bathroom. I did try the plastic baggy trick that another reviewer mentioned, which did make it a little easier.<br /><br />It seems other people like it a lot though. Maybe the product just doesn't work that well for me. I don't know. I just think it's easier to use other face masks that are already mixed into the form ready to apply and also find that other face masks leave my face feeling kind of the same afterward.<br /><br />I will say though, that this stuff does get incredibly tight when it's almost dry on my face and makes my face red for a little while after I take it off. That's what got me thinking that maybe it's doing something special. But, as I've said, my mind has yet to be blown by it :/
  1785. I love this stuff...it's so versatile...I use it in my hair and on my face...

  1831. A friend of mine who is a holistic health and wellness professional told me about this product when I asked her to recommend a natural mask without too many chemicals. When I found this online I thought it was too cheap to be good, but boy was I WRONG!!!! It is amazing and I use it on a weekly basis. You only need about 4 tblspn mixed with water or apple cider vinegar (I use ACV) and mix it into a thick paste - and then you spread it on your face to the thickness desired. I leave it on thick because I like the feeling of it. As it dries, your face gets pulled really tight and it really does throb/pulsate a little bit. After anywhere from 15 to 30 minutes you wash it off with a warn washcloth. As I learned the hard way, do not let the little dried pieces go down the sink, as it will get clogged. Your face feels really dry afterwards and gets really red, but will wear off after 5 to 10 minutes and then feel really soft. It feels as if after using this for several months, my skin definitely feels detoxed and clean. Also - it lasts forever!! Highly recommend it to anyone looking for a more natural face mask that is not expensive, and detoxifying.

  1868. I've had problematic skin since forever- oily skin, serious blackheads, really stubborn acne of all sorts, scarring etc. When I was younger I tried wearing make up and different acne medications (both drugstore and doctor prescribed) nothing worked OR it just made my skin worse. For years I did nothing to my face and had to deal with whatever my skin decided to look like that day.<br /><br />This winter break my skin decided to go all out - I became fed up and was not about to go back to school with my face full of acne and blackheads. I tried Queen Helen's Mint Julep but found it only works for BIG zits and if I put it all over my face it'll cause more breakouts. I've also tried Freemans Cucumber Peel but it's way too sticky, messy, and I find the it only takes off what's on the surface- not whats in your pores.<br /><br />After doing A LOT of research I found this product. Here's my view:<br /><br />This is a powder that you have to mix with either RAW Apple Cider or Water (I've heard you can also use Cranberry juice if you have SUPER oily skin but I haven't tried it). I personally like that it's a powder because it'll last a lot longer- I can just mix the right amount I need just for that moment. However, the process can be prettymessy. The instructions say not to use metal tools because it'll react with the clay. I used some plastic measuring tools from the dollar store and plastic mini disposable cups from walgreens (unless you want to be washing out bowls extensively I suggest using disposables).<br /><br />I poured in an equal part of Raw Cider and the clay began to fizz - it freaked me out a little but I continued to mix and it went away. I applied it to my face as instructed and waited. At first I didn't feel 'pulsating' but it definitely was sucking my skin to the point where my eyes and lips looked bigger. You do not want to peel this off- use a face towel with warm water. The first time my face had some redness- which is normal after a few minutes it went away.<br /><br />I was really shocked at how clean and light my skin felt. Even though I don't wearing makeup it felt like I was wearing heavy foundation or something before. I literally couldn't feel any icky-ness or heaviness on my face whatsoever and my pore were substantially smaller. I did it another two times- my black heads were almost completely gone and my acne was begin its healing process already! The bad part is that it left the rest of my skin really dry.<br /><br />I waited until the next day to use it again and found that I had smaller breakouts beginning to emerge and blackheads emerging as well. I did a 'steam' on my face to open my pore and only placed this clay on my acne areas and blackheads. After putting it on my blackheads a second time my nose was COMPLETELY clear- it was shocking. At this point I do feel pulsing when I put the clay on.<br /><br />BE AWARE that this only cleans out your face ( I mean REALLY cleans it out) it does not PROTECT your face from impurities getting back into your skin. So you have to find a lotion or moisturizer that'll keep all that bad stuff out. I used Neutrogena Acne Lotion which is okay for a day or so- I may switch to another. Your skin will be really dry afterwards so make sure you have a moisturizer at hand even if you have oily skin.<br /><br />I suggest you use this once or twice a week on your whole face and then however often you need it just on those problem areas. I wouldn't say use this at night before you go to bed because it won't do any good- a cleanser works much better for before-bed routines. This is more of a morning or emergency treatment thing when you need immediate or drastic results.<br /><br />As for acne scarring it really doesn't do much, in fact it may actually make them more apparent so a scar treatment or good exfoliator is a good idea also if you have issues with that.t away.<br /><br />I was really shocked at how clean and light my skin felt. Even though I don't wearing makeup it felt like I was wearing heavy foundation or something before. I literally couldn't feel any icky-ness or heaviness on my face whatsoever and my pore were substantially smaller. I did it another two times- my black heads were almost completely gone and my acne was begin its healing process already! The bad part is that it left the rest of my skin really dry.<br /><br />I waited until the next day to use it again and found that I had smaller breakouts beginning to emerge and blackheads emerging as well. I did a 'steam' on my face to open my pore and only placed this clay on my acne areas and blackheads. After putting it on my blackheads a second time my nose was COMPLETELY clear- it was shocking. At this point I do feel pulsing when I put the clay on.<br /><br />BE AWARE that this only cleans out your face ( I mean REALLY cleans it out) it does not PROTECT your face from impurities getting back into your skin. So you have to find a lotion or moisturizer that'll keep all that bad stuff out. I used Neutrogena Acne Lotion which is okay for a day or so- I may switch to another. Your skin will be really dry afterwards so make sure you have a moisturizer at hand even if you have oily skin.<br /><br />I suggest you use this once or twice a week on your whole face and then however often you need it just on those problem areas. I wouldn't say use this at night before you go to bed because it won't do any good- a cleanser works much better for before-bed routines. This is more of a morning or emergency treatment thing when you need immediate or drastic results.<br /><br />As for acne scarring it really doesn't do much, in fact it may actually make them more apparent so a scar treatment or good exfoliator is a good idea also if you have issues with that.
  1869. THis product is fantastic. I use it with the apple cider vinegar and it is amazing how well it cleans my face. I have really oily skin and I use this once a week to deep clean. Just try it and you will notice the benefits right away.
  1870. This is a great clay mask that works really well. The best time to use it is right after a shower, when your pores are steamed open. Mix it up with apple cider vinegar (it says you can also use water, but it's a waste of the product to use it - doesn't mix properly/react with the dry clay) and slather it on your face (or anywhere else I suppose). The sensation of the clay & apple cider vinegar is weird - pulsating, sucking sensations and it dries very stiff. Use a washcloth to get it off when it's dry as it's harder to take off than a normal clay mask. Your face will be a bit red-looking for ~15 minutes after, but it calms down. Really clears the pores, and is fun!

  1874. I recommend using this product with the apple cider vinegar and not mixing it with water. I tried mixing it with water and it came out very clumpy even after mixing and mashing thoroughly. The fizzing action of the apple cider vinegar helps the powder to dissolve fully. Using the recommended portion on the instructions makes waaay too much if you intend on using it as a face mask only. I usually use 1 tablespoon of the clay mix, and 2 tablespoons of the apple cider vinegar, and there is still leftovers. It does smell pretty awful when mixed with the vinegar, but gets better as it dries.<br /><br />I agree with other reviewers about the burning sensation. It feels like I am having an allergic reaction of some type, to describe the burning sensation. It's not extremely intense but manageable. It goes away after taking it off. The best way to describe the \\"pulsating\\" is like your pores are suffocated of oxygen and you can feel a \\"heart beat\\" pulse over your entire face.<br /><br />It has made my pores smaller, and my acne more manageable, but it hasn't completely solved that issue. I only use it a couple times a week though, because it is very drying and can cause irritation, which is why I took off one star.

  1911. I bought this item a few months back and have waited to write a review. I wanted to get a real sense of how well this works before writing a review: the wait was well worth it.<br /><br />I have struggled with body acne (mostly my back) since my teen years. This has hindered me from wearing swim suits, backless dresses, cute tank tops, etc. It has limited my clothing choices and has made me insecure when it comes to exposing my back (which is a shame, as I am in great shape and it would be a good asset otherwise).<br /><br />Well, I am happy to report that the healing clay has FINALLY cleared my back! I've recently purchased super adorable backless shirts and tanks as a celebratory notion.<br /><br />The acne is GONE and my large pores have shrunk. Yep. This stuff is cheap, easy to use and it, most importantly, ACTUALLY WORKS.<br /><br />I've tried the body washes for acne. I've eliminated heavy conditioners in my shower routine. I've tried rewashing my back after shampooing and conditioning. Nothing has worked...except for *this* product..<br /><br />Simply buy apple cider vinegar (I use Bragg's) and mix equal parts healing clay in a plastic cup or other plastic device of your choice. I don't over complicate this: I simply use my hands to apply the mixture. Your palms might feel slightly taut afterward, but that's about it. I see no need in spending any extra money on application devices, etc.<br /><br />You'll actually *feel* this product working. It'll tingle, evoke a cooling sensation and get tighter as it dries on the skin. I leave it on for about 15 minutes per application. Once dried, I simply use a washcloth and warm water to scrub it off with. It is THAT simple.<br /><br />I use this a few times a week. Like anything else, it is a balancing act. You just have to find out what your particular skin type needs. If you're oilier (and the back tends to get very oily--hence the acne problem...), then you'll need this more. I image that this product is rougher on the face than on the body; I've yet to try it on my facial skin.<br /><br />WARNING: Your skin will be red after using this item. You might even experience redness that is literally similar to a sunburn or a rash. This can be alarming at first, but rest assured that the redness *will* subside in 15-30 minutes time. The first time this happened to me I did freak out a bit! I just feel that potential buyers should know about this. I'm presuming that it is due to the pulling of the clay as it dries...and/or the vinegar. I don't think it is a harmful effect as much as a minor annoyance.<br />Buy this now if you've experience body breakouts. I can nearly promise that you'll be happy with the results.the face than on the body; I've yet to try it on my facial skin.<br /><br />WARNING: Your skin will be red after using this item. You might even experience redness that is literally similar to a sunburn or a rash. This can be alarming at first, but rest assured that the redness *will* subside in 15-30 minutes time. I'm presuming that it is due to the pulling of the clay as it dries...and/or the vinegar. I use it maybe once or twice a week depending on the weather and my oil production. I have combination skin so it can be drying on the cheeks. After some tries, I figured out that it's best to put on a THIN layer rather than a thick layer because the mask will take too long to dry. If you make a thick layer it'll start drying out fast at the edges first, which results in pulling on the skin on the edges. Since my goal is to tighten my pores evenly (especially the face center, or nose area) I make sure that I put on a pretty thin layer. I think it also helps with blood circulation to the face. Oh, and it's quite fun to see how my face changes (esp eyes and lips) as this dries hahaha

  1935. I've used this mask four times now, using it every other day. It really does help draw \\"stuff\\" (ie. black heads) to the surface for easier cleansing. I am in the midst of a pretty bad breakout, and though I don't think it's done much for the existing acne, I think it may be preventing the breakout from going any further, since it's purging my pores each time. It may be slowly helping and I'm just not being patient enough. What I can say is this... my face (where not broken out) feels absolutely amazing after using this mask. It's smooth and glowing.<br /><br />I did not find this product hard to use OR hard to clean up. I mixed it w/ the Bragg's Apple Cider Vinegar and would recommend that you do it this way, since the vinegar alone has been known to help clear acne (if that's what you're going for... I have began putting the vinegar alone on my face at night; we'll see how that goes). I put on a semi-thick (1/4\\"?) layer and let dry for 30 minutes. At the end of the 30 minutes, you are ready to have the stuff off of your face, but it's not extremely uncomfortable, either. I can see where people get the 'black hole' thing, but it's honestly NOT that bad. It's different; that's all. Just a different sensation than what you're used to.<br /><br />How I remove the mask is by wetting a wash cloth with very warm water, and gently pressing it against a large area of skin for a few seconds. Then I gently rub, rinse the cloth, and repeat until it's gone. It takes less than 5 minutes. I have not had issues w/ it staining towels or anything. You get a LOT for your money. I've been using 1 tsp mask & 2 tsp vinegar per mask.<br /><br />Overall, I think this is a pretty great product. I would recommend it as a \\"maintenance\\" skin care product, because I really do think it does what it says regarding removing gunk from your pores.

  1945. I have recently been trying to find a more natural and organic skin care routine. I have combination skin that can be a bit sensitive. I also have an uneven skin tone.For awhile now I have been using this routine:<br /><br />Dr Woods Black Soap with shea butter as a facial cleanser and body wash<br />Witch Hazel for a facial toner<br />Burts Bees Radiance Day Cream as a daytime moisturizer<br />Rosehip Oil for a night time moisturizer<br /><br />I also use an Aztec Clay Mask once a week for a deep clean.<br />Coconut Oil for an overall body lotion.<br />And I use a Konjac Sponge for a more natural version of a loofah.<br /><br />I am so far really loving this routine. And to be perfectly honest, the only reason I am using a separate moisturizer for daytime and nighttime is I already owned he Burts Bees Day Cream.<br /><br /> The Black Soap is a castile soap. I find it makes my skin very clean and surprisingly soft. The smell is okay. It smells like...well, soap. It does not smell like you are in a field of flowers or surrounded by mangoes like most beauty products do, but I am okay with that. I do not find the smell bad at all, just different then what I am used to from more normal products. It can also be used to wash your hair, but I have yet to try that. I have however tried it as a cleaner while doing the dishes and I found it worked well as a household cleaner as well.<br /><br />I love witch hazel. It is a great toner. It feels refreshing and exactly like any other toner I have ever used. But it is better as I feel a sense of joy everytime I use it as I know I am not putting any weird harsh chemicals on my skin when using it. If you don’t use toners, I highly recommend it. There are plenty of websites out there that show all the benefits of using a toner between a cleanser and a moisturizer.<br /><br />The Burts Bees Day Cream. I love the smell, it is in a cute little bottle, and my skin feels ready to tackle the day after using it. I am a big fan of most of the Burts Bees products so it makes sense that I like this too. I will however attempt to just use rosehip oil as a moisturizer once this cream is gone, simply because it would be more simplistic to just have 1 and it will save me some money. If that doesn’t work, I will gladly reorder this cream.<br /><br />Rosehip Oil is my new love when it comes to beauty products. It has recently gained popularity when model Miranda Kerr admitted to using it nightly on her skin. The smell isn’t good or bad. Meaning that it doesn’t smell wonderful like a perfume, but the smell isn’t bad and take away from the awesomeness of this product. If you don’t like the smell of it, don’t worry. It absorbs very quickly into your skin and the smell goes away once it does. It makes my skin so SMOOTH! And as I said, it absorbs very quickly which I love. I only use around 2-3 drops a night to cover my whole face. SO it will last quite awhile. I also love all the benefits it has. Again, there are plenty of websites out there that preach the amazing reasons to use this essential oil.<br /><br />I am sure by now we all know the lovely product that is coconut oil. It makes a fantastic lotion. My skin has never been more smooth in my life. The only downside in my opinion is it does not absorb quite as fast into my skin as the rosehip oil does. So I usually put this on first and let it start to work and then do the rest of my routine( hair, brush teeth, face, etc).<br /><br />The Aztec Clay Mask is such a simplistic face mask, yet it works better than any I have every used. It is especially useful for people who struggle with acne. I simply mix it with some Apple Cider Vinegar and put it on. I think go do a few chores like the dishes or starting laundry. I wash it off in the shower. Some don’t prefer to do this, but I haven’t had any problems doing so and I prefer to do it this way as it makes less of a mess in my opinion. I strongly encourage you all to try it.<br /><br />The KonjacSponges are a new addition to my routine. They are made from a plant root and another natural ingredient. They are expected to last around 3 months. Even longer if you take better care of them. They are so soft! And I can already tell it helps make my skin more smooth. I find them to definitely be a positive addition to my skincare routine and will be buying more. I use the pink clay facial sponge for my face cleaning. The pink clay helps with dry skin and uneven skin tone. There are a lot of varieties of different ingredients added to the sponges, so I am sure you can find one that works best for your skin. I then use the red clay body sponge for the same reasons. I have really dry skin and these help. I also feel a bit indulgent every time I use them because of how soft they are!<br /><br />I hope this has helped if you are like me and looking to lessen the amount of chemicals you put on your skin. Next I plan to try and make a more natural hair care routine, and then find natural alternatives for deodorant and toothpaste.Sponges are a new addition to my routine. Give it 15 minutes +- and wash it off (I just rinse in the shower, so far no clogs).
